cards.easyContent: Attorney-client privilege protects confidential communications between a client (including organizational clients) and an attorney made to obtain legal services, subject to limited exceptions.
cards.mediumContent: The attorney-client privilege covers confidential communications between an attorney and a client or the client’s authorized representatives that are made to facilitate legal services. It does not apply when the client seeks advice to commit a crime or fraud or when the attorney defends against a malpractice or similar claim. In joint representations, there is no privilege between the joint clients in later disputes between them, though the privilege still applies against third parties. Fee arrangements and payment records are generally not privileged.
cards.hardContent: Attorney-client privilege protects communications between an attorney and a client, including communications through the client’s representatives, so long as they are intended to be confidential and made to facilitate legal services. For organizational clients, the privilege extends to communications by employees authorized to speak to counsel. The privilege does not apply under the crime-fraud exception when legal services are sought to plan or commit a crime or fraud, or when the attorney defends against malpractice or other claims alleging breach of duty. In joint representations, an attorney’s communications with both clients are not privileged in subsequent litigation between those clients, although the privilege can be asserted in disputes with third parties. Records of fee arrangements and payments are generally outside the scope of the privilege.
cards.mnemonic: CFL: Confidential, for Legal advice, between Client and Lawyer.
cards.clozeLite: Attorney-client privilege protects {{c1::confidential communications}} {{c2::between attorney and client or reps}} {{c3::made to facilitate legal services}} {{c4::subject to crime-fraud and malpractice-claim exceptions}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Doctor Patient Privilege and Therapist/Social Worker Client Privilege
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 022. Doctor Patient Privilege and Therapist/Social Worker Client Privilege
cards.front: Doctor Patient Privilege and Therapist/Social Worker Client Privilege – Overview
cards.backPlain: Doctor–patient and psychotherapist/social worker–patient privileges protect certain confidential treatment-related communications from disclosure. 1. Physician–patient privilege (statutory; generally applied via state law in federal court): 1.1. Protects information confidentially conveyed by a patient to a physician. 1.2. Applies to communications made for purposes of diagnosis or treatment, that are pertinent to diagnosis or treatment, and that the patient intends to be confidential. 1.3. Subject to specific exceptions, including when the patient’s condition is in issue, when the physician’s services are sought to aid a crime or tort or escape capture, and when there is a dispute between doctor and patient. 2. Psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege: 2.1. Protects confidential communications by a client to a psychotherapist or social worker. 2.2. Applies in civil and criminal cases when the client intends confidentiality and the communication is made to facilitate therapy or social work. 2.3. Operates in most respects like the attorney–client privilege.
cards.frontPrompt: How do physician–patient and psychotherapist/social worker–patient privileges protect confidential treatment communications, and what are the main requirements and limits at a high level?

Protects information confidentially conveyed by a {{c4::patient to a physician}}. 1.2. Applies to communications made for purposes of {{c5::diagnosis or treatment}}, that are {{c6::pertinent to diagnosis or treatment}}, and that the patient {{c7::intends to be confidential}}. 1.3. Subject to specific {{c8::exceptions}} (e.g., condition in issue, crime/tort/escape, doctor–patient dispute). 2. {{c9::Psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege}}: 2.1. Protects {{c10::confidential communications}} by a client to a psychotherapist or social worker. 2.2. Applies in {{c11::civil and criminal cases}} when the client intends confidentiality and the communication is made to {{c12::facilitate therapy or social work}}. 2.3. Operates in most respects like the {{c13::attorney–client privilege}}.
cards.easyContent: Physician–patient and psychotherapist/social worker–patient privileges protect confidential communications made for diagnosis, treatment, or therapy. Doctor–patient privilege is statutory and applied via state law in federal courts, has specific requirements, and has key exceptions (condition in issue, crime/tort/escape, and doctor–patient disputes). Psychotherapist and social worker–patient privilege broadly protects confidential therapy-related communications in civil and criminal cases and operates like attorney–client privilege.
cards.mediumContent: Physician–patient privilege (a statutory, state-law-based privilege in federal court) protects confidential patient communications made to a physician for diagnosis or treatment, when pertinent and intended to be confidential, but is subject to important exceptions such as when the patient’s condition is in issue, when services are sought to commit a crime or tort or escape capture, or when doctor and patient are in dispute. Psychotherapist and social worker–patient privilege protects confidential client communications made to facilitate therapy or social work in civil and criminal cases and largely mirrors the attorney–client privilege.
cards.hardContent: Physician–patient privilege is a statutory privilege (not codified in the FRE) generally applied in federal court through state law that bars disclosure of information confidentially conveyed by a patient to a physician for purposes of diagnosis or treatment, so long as it is pertinent to that diagnosis or treatment and intended to be confidential, subject to exceptions when the patient’s condition is itself in issue, when the physician’s services are sought to aid a crime, tort, or escape from capture, or when there is a dispute between doctor and patient. In parallel, psychotherapist and social worker–patient privilege protects confidential client communications made to facilitate therapy or social work in all civil and criminal cases, and in most respects functions like the attorney–client privilege.

cards.topic: Spousal Testimony and Marital Communications Privilege
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 023. Spousal Testimony and Marital Communications Privilege
cards.front: Spousal Testimony and Marital Communications Privilege
cards.backPlain: 1. Spousal testimonial privilege. 1.1. Applies in criminal cases only. 1.2. A person whose spouse is a defendant in a criminal case cannot be called as a witness by the prosecution or compelled to testify against the spouse in the criminal proceeding. 1.3. Only the witness-spouse may invoke the privilege (the defendant cannot prevent a willing spouse from testifying against the defendant). 1.4. The privilege can only be invoked during a valid marriage. 2. Marital communications privilege. 2.1. Applies in both civil and criminal cases. 2.2. Confidential communications made between spouses during marriage are privileged in any later proceeding. 2.3. The privilege applies even if the spouses divorce after the confidential communication was made. 2.4. Either spouse may invoke the privilege. 2.5. A spouse can lose the privilege as to his own use if he breaks confidentiality (i.e., relays a marital communication to a third party), but the other spouse still retains the privilege. 3. Exceptions where marital communications privilege does not apply. 3.1. Suits between spouses. 3.2. Suits in which one spouse is charged with a crime or tort against the couple’s children. 3.3. Suits in which spouses are co-defendants.
cards.frontPrompt: How do spousal testimonial privilege and marital communications privilege differ, and what are the main exceptions to marital communications privilege?

cards.easyContent: Spousal testimonial privilege lets the witness-spouse refuse to testify against a spouse in a criminal case during the marriage, while marital communications privilege protects confidential marital communications in civil and criminal cases, even after divorce, subject to certain exceptions.
cards.mediumContent: Spousal testimonial privilege applies only in criminal cases and allows the witness-spouse—not the defendant—to refuse to be called or compelled by the prosecution to testify against a spouse, but only while the spouses are validly married. Marital communications privilege applies in both civil and criminal cases to confidential communications made between spouses during marriage, continues even after divorce, and may be invoked by either spouse, though a spouse who discloses the communication waives it as to that spouse’s own use while the other spouse still holds it. The marital communications privilege does not apply in suits between spouses, in prosecutions or suits where one spouse is accused of a crime or tort against the couple’s children, or where spouses are co-defendants.
cards.hardContent: Spousal testimonial privilege is a criminal-only privilege that allows a person whose spouse is a defendant in a criminal case not to be called as a witness by the prosecution and not to be compelled to testify against the spouse; it belongs solely to the witness-spouse and can be invoked only during a valid marriage. Marital communications privilege applies in both civil and criminal cases and protects confidential communications made between spouses during marriage in any later proceeding; it survives divorce, and either spouse may invoke it. If one spouse discloses a marital communication to a third party, that spouse waives the privilege as to his or her own ability to claim it, but the other spouse retains the privilege. The marital communications privilege does not apply in suits between spouses, in actions where one spouse is charged with a crime or tort against the couple’s children, or in suits where the spouses are co-defendants.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 024. Authentication
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule. 1.1. Every item of physical evidence must be authenticated, meaning the proponent must show that the evidence is what the proponent claims it is. 1.2. Proving authentication: may be proved by any means that serve to establish authenticity (a low burden). For example, an item may be compared with an already authenticated item. 1.3. Self-authenticating evidence: certain writings that contain identifying information do not need separate authentication. For example, deeds, notarized documents, and newspapers. 2. Specific authentication issues. 2.1. Ancient documents (automatically authenticated if all are met): 2.1.1. The document is 20 or more years old. 2.1.2. It does not present any irregularities on its face. 2.1.3. It is found in a place of natural custody. 2.2. Photos: a witness with personal knowledge must authenticate by confirming that the photo fairly and accurately depicts what it purports to show (does the fact testified to equal the fact perceived?). 2.3. Voice: whether heard firsthand or through a recording, a voice may be identified by anyone who heard the voice at any time. 2.4. Non-unique items: 2.4.1. A non-unique item is facially indistinguishable from others of its kind (e.g., a bag of white powder, a generic syringe). 2.4.2. The proponent must establish that the proffered evidence is the same item it is claimed to be, usually through a chain of custody; the item will be admissible absent large breaks in the chain.

cards.easyContent: Authentication requires only a low-threshold showing that an item of evidence is what the proponent claims it is, which can be done in various ways including self-authenticating documents and special rules for ancient documents, photos, voices, and non-unique items.
cards.mediumContent: To authenticate evidence, the proponent must make a low-burden showing, by any method that tends to prove authenticity, that the item is what it is claimed to be; some documents are self-authenticating and need no further proof. Ancient documents are automatically authenticated if they are at least 20 years old, facially regular, and found in a natural place of custody. Photos are authenticated by a witness with personal knowledge who confirms they fairly and accurately depict what they purport to show. Voices may be identified by anyone who has heard the voice at any time, live or recorded. Non-unique items that are indistinguishable from others (like drugs or syringes) are authenticated by proof of a reliable chain of custody showing the item is the same one.
cards.hardContent: Authentication requires that the proponent offer evidence sufficient to support a finding that the physical evidence is what the proponent claims it is, a low burden that may be satisfied by any method that tends to establish authenticity, such as comparison with authenticated specimens. Certain writings, like deeds, notarized documents, and newspapers, are self-authenticating and need no additional proof. Ancient documents are deemed authenticated if the document is at least 20 years old, shows no facial irregularities, and is found in a place of natural custody. Photos are authenticated through a witness with personal knowledge who testifies that the photo fairly and accurately represents what it purports to depict. Voices may be authenticated by anyone who has heard the voice at any time, whether in person or via recording. Non-unique items, such as a bag of white powder, must be tied to the case by evidence—typically a chain of custody—showing that the exhibit is the same item and has not been materially altered; minor gaps generally go to weight, not admissibility, but large breaks can render the item inadmissible.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 025. Best Evidence Rule
cards.backPlain: 1. Best Evidence Rule (general rule). 1.1. If evidence is offered to prove the contents of a writing, an original document must be used unless it is unavailable. 1.2. A "writing" includes any tangible collection of data (e.g., videos, documents, photos, books, e-mails, text messages, computer drives, x-rays). 2. Applicability. 2.1. The rule applies only if the evidence is offered to prove the contents of the writing (e.g., a witness’s knowledge is obtained from a writing, or the case turns on the contents of a legal instrument). 3. Evidence sufficient to prove a writing’s contents. 3.1. Originals. 3.2. Duplicates: must be a machine or carbon copy and are admissible unless there is a genuine question as to the authenticity of the original itself. 3.3. Testimony regarding contents: admissible if the original is lost or destroyed, unless it was lost or destroyed in bad faith by the proponent of the testimony. 3.4. Voluminous documents exception: a voluminous series of documents may be summarized in court; the originals relied upon must be available for inspection. 4. Completeness doctrine. 4.1. If a party introduces part of a writing or recorded statement into evidence, an adverse party may introduce any other part—or any other writing or recorded statement—that in fairness should be considered at the same time.

cards.easyContent: The Best Evidence Rule requires an original (or acceptable substitute) when a party seeks to prove the contents of a writing, broadly defined as any tangible collection of data, and the completeness doctrine lets the opponent require related portions to be considered together for fairness.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Best Evidence Rule, when a party offers evidence to prove the contents of a writing—any tangible collection of data, such as documents, photos, or electronic records—the party must generally produce the original unless it is unavailable. The rule is triggered only when the contents themselves are at issue, such as when a witness’s knowledge comes from the writing or the dispute centers on a legal instrument’s terms. The contents can be proven by originals, by machine or carbon duplicates unless there is a genuine question about the original’s authenticity, by testimony if the original was lost or destroyed without bad faith by the proponent, or by summaries of voluminous documents so long as the originals are available for inspection. The completeness doctrine allows an adverse party to introduce any other part of a writing or related writings or recordings that in fairness should be considered at the same time as the portion introduced.
cards.hardContent: The Best Evidence Rule provides that when evidence is offered to prove the contents of a writing, the proponent must ordinarily produce the original document. A "writing" includes any tangible collection of data—such as videos, photographs, books, emails, text messages, computer drives, and x-rays—so the rule applies broadly but only when the contents are themselves in dispute or when a witness’s knowledge derives from the writing. The contents may be proved by originals, by duplicates that are true machine or carbon copies unless the original’s authenticity is genuinely challenged, or by testimony if the original has been lost or destroyed without bad faith by the proponent. For voluminous writings, the court may admit a summary, chart, or calculation, provided the underlying originals are available for inspection. Separately, the completeness doctrine allows an adverse party, when only part of a writing or recorded statement is offered, to require admission of any other part or related writing or recording that in fairness should be considered at the same time to avoid misleading the fact-finder.
cards.mnemonic: BEST: Base Evidence on Source Text (original/duplicate).
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::Best Evidence Rule}}, when a party seeks to {{c2::prove the contents of a writing}}, it must generally produce the {{c3::original or acceptable duplicate}}, and the {{c4::completeness doctrine}} lets the opponent require related portions be considered for {{c5::fairness}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 026. Judicial Notice
cards.backPlain: 1. Judicial notice (general rule). 1.1. A court may recognize a fact as true without formal presentation of evidence, either on its own or upon formal request of a party. 2. Judicially-noticeable facts. 2.1. Manifest facts: those capable of verification by a source that is not subject to reasonable dispute. 2.2. Notorious facts: those generally known within the jurisdiction. 3. Judicial notice of laws. 3.1. The court must take judicial notice of federal and state laws and regulations. 3.2. As to all other laws, the court has discretion to take judicial notice (for example, municipal ordinances or foreign laws). 4. Effect of judicially-noticed facts or laws. 4.1. Civil cases: the jury must accept judicially-noticed facts as conclusive. 4.2. Criminal cases: the jury may accept judicially-noticed facts as conclusive, but is not required to do so. 5. Judicial testimony. 5.1. A presiding judge may not testify as a witness at trial (no party may call the trial judge to testify).

cards.easyContent: Judicial notice lets a court accept certain manifest or generally known facts, and some laws, without proof; civil juries must accept noticed facts as conclusive, while criminal juries may but need not, and the trial judge cannot testify as a witness.
cards.mediumContent: A court may take judicial notice of facts without formal evidence when they are either manifest (capable of accurate and ready determination from sources not subject to reasonable dispute) or notorious (generally known within the jurisdiction). The court must judicially notice federal and state laws and regulations, but has discretion whether to notice other laws such as municipal ordinances or foreign law. In civil cases, judicially-noticed facts are binding on the jury, which must accept them as conclusive; in criminal cases, the jury may, but is not required to, accept them as conclusive. The presiding trial judge may not be called to testify as a witness at that trial.
cards.hardContent: Judicial notice allows a court to dispense with formal proof by recognizing certain facts as true without evidence, either sua sponte or at a party’s request. Judicially-noticeable facts include manifest facts—those capable of accurate and ready determination by sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned—and notorious facts that are generally known within the court’s territorial jurisdiction. The court must take judicial notice of federal and state laws and regulations but has discretion with respect to other laws, including municipal ordinances and foreign law. The effect differs by case type: in civil cases, the jury must accept judicially-noticed facts as conclusive; in criminal cases, the jury may but need not treat them as conclusive, preserving the defendant’s right to a jury determination of all elements. Additionally, the presiding judge is incompetent to testify as a witness at the trial over which the judge is presiding and may not be called by any party.
cards.mnemonic: Judicial notice: MN facts, Civil Must, Criminal May.
cards.clozeLite: Judicial notice covers {{c1::manifest (readily verifiable)}} and {{c2::notorious (generally known)}} facts and {{c3::laws}}; in {{c4::civil}} cases facts are {{c5::conclusive}}, in {{c6::criminal}} cases jury may reject them.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 027. Hearsay
cards.backPlain: Hearsay is an out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted. These statements are generally inadmissible, subject to certain exceptions and exemptions. 1. Statement 1.1 A "statement" is an oral or written assertion, or non-verbal conduct intended as an assertion. 1.2 Non-human assertions are not statements (e.g., test results, radar gun reading, dog barking). 1.3 Out-of-court statements are not hearsay if offered to prove anything other than the truth of the matter they assert. 2. Exemptions vs. exceptions (Federal Rules) 2.1 Exemptions: statements are deemed non-hearsay and thus admitted. 2.2 Exceptions: statements are deemed hearsay, but still admitted under an exception. 2.3 Beyond this distinction, there are no practical differences between hearsay exceptions and exemptions; they should be treated the same for admissibility. 2.4 Watch for answer choices that turn on this distinction. A witness's own prior out-of-court statement can be hearsay; thus, an answer that a statement is "not hearsay because the witness is on the stand" is incorrect.

A witness's own prior out-of-court statement can be hearsay; thus, an answer that a statement is "not hearsay because the witness is on the stand" is incorrect.
cards.easyContent: Hearsay is an out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of what it asserts and is generally inadmissible, subject to exceptions and exemptions. A statement must be an assertion by a person; non-human outputs are not statements.
cards.mediumContent: Hearsay is an out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted. A statement is an oral or written assertion or non-verbal conduct intended as an assertion, and non-human outputs like test results are not statements. Statements are not hearsay if offered for some purpose other than their truth. Under the Federal Rules, some statements are treated as non-hearsay via exemptions, while others are hearsay but admissible via exceptions, though in practice both are admitted.
cards.hardContent: Hearsay is an out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted and is generally inadmissible absent an exception or exemption. A "statement" is an oral or written assertion, or non-verbal conduct intended as an assertion; non-human assertions (such as test results, radar readings, or a dog barking) are not statements. Out-of-court statements are not hearsay when offered to prove something other than the truth they assert. Under the Federal Rules, exemptions deem certain categories of statements to be non-hearsay, while exceptions treat statements as hearsay but still admit them. In practice, both exemptions and exceptions result in admissibility, but answer choices may test the distinction. A witness’s own prior out-of-court statement can be hearsay even if the witness testifies at trial, so it is incorrect to say a statement is non-hearsay merely because the declarant is now on the stand.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 028. Admissible Out of Court Statements
cards.backPlain: Out-of-court statements are not hearsay if offered to prove anything other than the truth of the matter they assert. 1. Common non-hearsay out-of-court statements 1.1 Statements of independent legal significance 1.1.1 The statement contains legally operative words (e.g., words of offer, acceptance, defamation, or threats). 1.1.2 The statement is not hearsay because it is offered to show that the statement was made, not whether it was true. 1.1.3 For example: in a contract dispute, a witness testifies that B told A, "I accept your offer." 1.2 Statements offered to show their effect on the listener or reader 1.2.1 For example: in a negligence claim, a statement warning P of the injury-causing condition is admissible to show notice to P. 1.3 Statements offered to show speaker's knowledge 1.3.1 For example: D, charged with conspiracy, claims he did not know about the crime; a statement indicating D was told specifics of the crime is admissible to show he knew it was planned. 1.4 Statements offered to show state of mind 1.4.1 Statements offered as circumstantial evidence of the declarant's state of mind are not hearsay. 1.4.2 For example: a statement by D, before running into traffic and causing an accident, that he is invisible may be used to show insanity. 1.4.3 Compare with the state of mind hearsay exception, which allows hearsay statements that directly (not circumstantially) reflect the declarant's state of mind.

cards.easyContent: Out-of-court statements are not hearsay when offered for something other than their truth, including legally operative words, effect on the listener, knowledge, or as circumstantial evidence of state of mind.
cards.mediumContent: Out-of-court statements are not hearsay when offered for a non-truth purpose. Common categories include: (1) statements of independent legal significance, where the words themselves create legal rights or obligations; (2) statements offered to show their effect on the listener, such as notice; (3) statements offered to show the declarant or listener’s knowledge; and (4) statements offered as circumstantial evidence of the declarant's state of mind, as distinct from the state of mind hearsay exception, which admits statements that directly reflect state of mind.
cards.hardContent: Out-of-court statements are not hearsay when they are offered to prove something other than the truth of what they assert. Key categories include: (1) statements of independent legal significance, where the words themselves are legally operative (such as words of offer, acceptance, defamation, or threats) and are offered simply to show they were made; (2) statements offered to show their effect on the listener or reader, such as a warning introduced to show that a plaintiff had notice of a danger; (3) statements offered to show the speaker's or listener’s knowledge, for example, proof that a defendant was told the details of a planned crime to show he knew of the conspiracy; and (4) statements offered as circumstantial evidence of the declarant's state of mind, such as a declaration of being invisible to show insanity. These differ from the state of mind hearsay exception, which admits statements that directly reflect the declarant’s then-existing state of mind.
cards.mnemonic: L-E-K-M: Legal words, Effect, Knowledge, Mind-state (circumstantial).
cards.clozeLite: Out-of-court statements are not hearsay when offered for {{c1::a non-truth purpose}}, including {{c2::independent legal significance}}, {{c3::effect on listener}}, {{c4::knowledge}}, or {{c5::circumstantial state of mind}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 029. Non Hearsay Exemptions
cards.backPlain: 1. Statements of a party-opponent 1.1 Out-of-court statements by a party are admissible if offered against that party. 1.2 Judicial statements: statements made in pleadings or testimony may be used against the party. 1.3 Adoptive statement: a party's acquiescence in another's statement can be treated as the party's own statement. 1.4 Silence: can be a statement or admission if: 1.4.1 The party heard, understood, and was capable of responding; and 1.4.2 A reasonable person in the party's position would have responded. 2. Vicarious statements 2.1 A vicarious statement is a statement by someone other than the person against whom the statement is offered. 2.2 Agency: a statement by an agent or employee on matters within the scope of the agency or employment and made during the relationship is admissible against the principal. 2.3 Authorized speaker: a statement by a person authorized by a party to speak on her behalf is admissible against the party. 2.4 Co-conspirator: a co-conspirator's statements are admissible against a defendant if made during and in furtherance of the conspiracy. 3. Declarant-witness's prior statements 3.1 A prior statement by a declarant who testifies and is subject to cross-examination is admissible and treated as non-hearsay if it is: 3.1.1 Inconsistent with the declarant's testimony and given under oath at a prior proceeding or deposition. 3.1.2 A prior consistent statement offered to rebut a charge of fabrication, improper motive or influence, or to rehabilitate credibility. 3.1.3 A prior statement of identification after perception, used to identify a person the declarant perceived earlier.

cards.easyContent: Under the Federal Rules, certain statements are treated as non-hearsay, including statements of a party-opponent, some vicarious statements (agents, authorized speakers, co-conspirators), and specified prior statements of a testifying, cross-examinable witness.
cards.mediumContent: Non-hearsay exemptions include: (1) statements of a party-opponent, including the party’s own statements, judicial admissions, adoptive admissions (such as acquiescence), and sometimes silence when a reasonable person would deny; (2) vicarious statements, such as statements by agents or employees within the scope of and during the agency, authorized spokespersons, and co-conspirators’ statements made during and in furtherance of the conspiracy; and (3) certain prior statements by a declarant who testifies and is subject to cross, namely prior inconsistent statements under oath, prior consistent statements used to rebut charges of fabrication or improper motive, and prior identifications made after perceiving a person.
cards.hardContent: The Federal Rules treat several categories of statements as non-hearsay. First, statements of a party-opponent include a party’s own out-of-court statements when offered against that party, judicial statements made in pleadings or testimony, adoptive admissions where the party manifests agreement with another’s statement, and silence when the party heard, understood, and could respond, and a reasonable person would deny the statement. Second, vicarious statements include statements by agents or employees about matters within the scope of and during the agency or employment, statements by persons authorized to speak on a party’s behalf, and co-conspirators’ statements made during and in furtherance of the conspiracy, all of which are admissible against the party. Third, a declarant-witness’s prior statements are non-hearsay if the declarant testifies and is subject to cross-examination and the prior statement is (a) inconsistent with current testimony and was given under oath at a prior proceeding or deposition, (b) a prior consistent statement offered to rebut a charge of fabrication, improper influence, or motive, or to rehabilitate credibility, or (c) a prior identification made after perceiving a person.

cards.easyContent: Hearsay exceptions are divided into two groups: those that require the declarant to be unavailable (like former testimony, statements against interest, dying declarations, certain history, and wrongdoing-caused unavailability) and those where availability does not matter (like excited utterances, present sense impressions, medical statements, business and public records, and similar categories).
cards.mediumContent: Some hearsay exceptions apply only if the declarant is unavailable, including former testimony, statements against interest, dying declarations, statements of personal or family history, and statements offered against a party who wrongfully caused the declarant’s unavailability. Many other exceptions apply regardless of availability, such as present state of mind, excited utterances, present sense impressions, statements of physical condition for diagnosis or treatment, past recollection recorded, business and public records, judgments and prior convictions, ancient documents, documents affecting property interests, learned treatises, family records, and market reports or similar commercial publications.
cards.hardContent: The hearsay exceptions can be organized by the declarant’s availability. 1) When unavailability is required (FRE 804), the key exceptions are: former testimony; statements against interest; dying declarations; statements of personal or family history; and statements offered against a party that wrongfully caused or procured the declarant’s unavailability. 2) When availability is immaterial, the main exceptions include: present state of mind; excited utterances; present sense impressions; statements of physical condition for purposes of medical diagnosis or treatment; past recollection recorded; business records; public records or reports; judgments and prior convictions; ancient documents; documents affecting property interests; learned treatises; family records; and market reports or similar commercial publications.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 031. Exceptions Requiring Declarant Unavailability
cards.backPlain: 1. Exceptions that require declarant to be unavailable 1.1 Former testimony. 1.2 Statements against interest. 1.3 Dying declarations. 1.4 Statements of personal or family history. 1.5 Statements offered against a party that wrongfully procured the declarant's unavailability. 2. Meaning of "unavailable" 2.1 "Unavailability" refers to the declarant's ability to testify. 2.2 For example: a declarant can be physically present in court but still be legally "unavailable" because she asserts a valid privilege. 2.3 A declarant is unavailable if any of the following applies: 2.3.1 Privilege: exempt from testifying due to a recognized privilege. 2.3.2 Death or physical/mental sickness that prevents testimony. 2.3.3 Refusal to testify despite a court order. 2.3.4 Lack of memory regarding the subject matter. 2.3.5 Absence: beyond the reach of the court's subpoena power, and the statement's proponent has not been able to procure the declarant's attendance or testimony by reasonable means.
cards.frontPrompt: Which hearsay exceptions require that the declarant be unavailable, and what situations qualify a declarant as "unavailable"?
cards.cloze: 1. Exceptions that require declarant to be {{c1::unavailable}} 1.1 {{c2::Former testimony}}. 1.2 {{c3::Statements against interest}}. 1.3 {{c4::Dying declarations}}. 1.4 Statements of {{c5::personal or family history}}. 1.5 Statements offered against a party that {{c6::wrongfully procured the declarant's unavailability}}. 2. Meaning of "unavailable" 2.1 "Unavailability" refers to the declarant's {{c7::ability to testify}}. 2.2 For example: a declarant can be physically present in court but still be legally "unavailable" because she asserts a valid {{c8::privilege}}. 2.3 A declarant is unavailable if any of the following applies: 2.3.1 {{c9::Privilege}}: exempt from testifying due to a recognized privilege. 2.3.2 {{c10::Death or physical/mental sickness}} that prevents testimony. 2.3.3 {{c11::Refusal to testify}} despite a court order. 2.3.4 {{c12::Lack of memory}} regarding the subject matter. 2.3.5 {{c13::Absence}}: beyond the reach of the court's subpoena power, and the statement's proponent has not been able to procure the declarant's attendance or testimony by reasonable means.
cards.easyContent: Some hearsay exceptions apply only if the declarant is unavailable, including former testimony, statements against interest, dying declarations, certain family-history statements, and statements offered against a party who caused the unavailability. A declarant is unavailable if they cannot or will not testify for specific reasons like privilege, death, illness, refusal, lack of memory, or absence beyond subpoena power.
cards.mediumContent: Exceptions requiring unavailability include former testimony, statements against interest, dying declarations, statements of personal or family history, and statements offered against a party who wrongfully caused the declarant's unavailability. A declarant is "unavailable" when they cannot provide testimony, even if physically present, due to a valid privilege, death or serious physical/mental illness, refusal to testify despite court order, claimed lack of memory, or being beyond subpoena reach despite reasonable efforts to secure their presence or testimony.
cards.hardContent: The hearsay exceptions that require the declarant to be unavailable are: (1) former testimony, given under oath at a prior proceeding with an opportunity and similar motive to cross-examine; (2) statements against interest, which were against the declarant’s pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest when made; (3) dying declarations, made under a sense of impending death about the cause or circumstances of what the declarant believed to be impending death; (4) statements of personal or family history; and (5) statements offered against a party that wrongfully procured the declarant’s unavailability. A declarant is considered "unavailable" if they are unable or unwilling to testify, including when they assert a valid privilege, are dead or so physically or mentally ill that they cannot testify, refuse to testify despite a court order, claim a lack of memory of the subject matter, or are absent beyond the court’s subpoena power and cannot be brought to court despite reasonable efforts by the proponent.
cards.mnemonic: Unavailability exceptions: FADS-FW—Former, Against interest, Dying, Status, Forfeiture Wrongdoing.
cards.clozeLite: Unavailability exceptions: {{c1::former testimony}}, {{c2::statements against interest}}, {{c3::dying declarations}}, {{c4::personal/family history}}, and {{c5::forfeiture by wrongdoing}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 032. Former Testimony
cards.backPlain: Former testimony is admissible hearsay if the following requirements are met: 1. Declarant is unavailable. 2. The prior testimony was given under oath. 3. The party against whom the testimony is now offered was either: 3.1 A party in the previous action and had an opportunity to cross-examine the declarant; and 3.2 Had a similar motive for cross-examining the declarant in the former hearing as in the current proceeding; or 3.3 A predecessor in interest of a party in the previous action, in which there was an opportunity to cross-examine the declarant and a similar motive for doing so. 3.4 A predecessor in interest is one who has a close privity-type relationship with the party in the earlier proceeding. 4. This exception applies in civil actions only. 5. The MBE frequently tests this exception; remember that it only applies if the declarant is unavailable and the prior testimony was under oath.
cards.frontPrompt: When is former testimony admissible under the hearsay exception in civil cases? State the requirements.
cards.cloze: Former testimony is admissible {{c1::hearsay}} if the following requirements are met: 1. Declarant is {{c2::unavailable}}. 2. The prior testimony was given {{c3::under oath}}. 3. The party against whom the testimony is now offered was either: 3.1 A {{c4::party in the previous action}} and had an {{c5::opportunity to cross-examine}} the declarant; and 3.2 Had a {{c6::similar motive for cross-examining}} the declarant in the former hearing as in the current proceeding; or 3.3 A {{c7::predecessor in interest}} of a party in the previous action, in which there was an opportunity to cross-examine the declarant and a similar motive for doing so. 3.4 A predecessor in interest is one who has a {{c8::close privity-type relationship}} with the party in the earlier proceeding. 4. This exception applies in {{c9::civil actions only}}. 5. The MBE frequently tests this exception; remember that it only applies if the declarant is {{c10::unavailable}} and the prior testimony was {{c11::under oath}}.
cards.easyContent: Former testimony is admissible if the declarant is unavailable, the prior testimony was under oath, and the opposing party (or predecessor in interest) previously had an opportunity and similar motive to cross-examine, in a civil case.
cards.mediumContent: Former testimony is admissible hearsay in civil cases when: (1) the declarant is unavailable; (2) the prior testimony was under oath; and (3) the party against whom it is offered was either a party in the earlier action or a predecessor in interest who had an opportunity and similar motive to cross-examine the declarant.
cards.hardContent: Former testimony is a hearsay exception when: (1) the declarant is unavailable; (2) the earlier testimony was given under oath; and (3) the party against whom it is now offered was a party in the prior action or a predecessor in interest, had an opportunity to cross-examine the declarant, and had a similar motive to do so as in the present case. A predecessor in interest is one in a close privity-type relationship with the party. This exception is limited to civil actions. The MBE often tests that unavailability and oath are required.
cards.mnemonic: U-O-P: Unavailable, Oath, Prior opportunity and similar motive.
cards.clozeLite: Former {{c1::testimony}} is admissible if the {{c2::declarant is unavailable}}, was {{c3::under oath}}, and the opponent had {{c4::opportunity and similar motive to cross}} in a {{c5::civil case}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 033. Statements Against Interest
cards.backPlain: A hearsay statement is admissible if, at the time it was made, it was against the pecuniary, proprietary, penal, or legal interests of the declarant. 1. Requirements for statement against interest (statement is admissible if): 1.1 Declarant is currently unavailable. 1.2 The statement was contrary to the declarant's pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest when made. 1.3 A reasonable person would not have made the statement unless he believed it to be true. 1.4 In criminal cases, there must also be corroborating circumstances indicating the trustworthiness of the statement. 2. Distinguish from party-opponent admissions: 2.1 A party-opponent admission is a statement of a party or a vicarious statement attributable to that party. 2.2 There is no requirement that the statement is against the declarant's interest. 2.3 A statement against interest is any statement against the declarant's interest at the time it was made. 2.4 There is no requirement that the declarant is a party in the proceeding.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for the hearsay exception for statements against interest, and how does it differ from a party-opponent admission?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::hearsay}} statement is admissible if, at the time it was made, it was against the {{c2::pecuniary, proprietary, penal, or legal interests}} of the declarant. 1. Requirements for {{c3::statement against interest}} (statement is admissible if): 1.1 Declarant is currently {{c4::unavailable}}. 1.2 The statement was contrary to the declarant's {{c5::pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest}} when made. 1.3 A {{c6::reasonable person}} would not have made the statement unless he believed it to be true. 1.4 In {{c7::criminal cases}}, there must also be {{c8::corroborating circumstances}} indicating the {{c9::trustworthiness}} of the statement. 2. Distinguish from {{c10::party-opponent admissions}}: 2.1 A party-opponent admission is a statement of a {{c11::party}} or a {{c12::vicarious statement attributable to that party}}. 2.2 There is {{c13::no requirement that the statement is against the declarant's interest}}. 2.3 A statement against interest is any statement against the {{c14::declarant's interest at the time it was made}}. 2.4 There is {{c15::no requirement that the declarant is a party}} in the proceeding.
cards.easyContent: A statement against interest is admissible hearsay if the declarant is unavailable, the statement was against the declarant’s pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest when made, and a reasonable person would not have made it unless true; criminal cases also require corroboration.
cards.mediumContent: For the statement-against-interest exception, the declarant must be unavailable, the statement must have been against the declarant’s pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest when made, and a reasonable person would not have said it unless it was true; in criminal cases, there must be corroborating circumstances indicating trustworthiness. Unlike a party-opponent admission, the declarant need not be a party, and the statement must actually be against the declarant’s interest.
cards.hardContent: A statement against interest is admissible as a hearsay exception when: (1) the declarant is unavailable; (2) the statement was contrary to the declarant’s pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest at the time it was made; and (3) a reasonable person in the declarant’s position would not have made the statement unless believing it to be true. In criminal cases, there must also be corroborating circumstances indicating the statement’s trustworthiness. This differs from a party-opponent admission, which is any statement of a party (or attributable vicarious statement), need not be against interest, and does not require that the declarant be unavailable or even a party for a statement against interest.
cards.mnemonic: "HURT": Hiding (unavailable), Unfavorable, Reasonable not to say, Trustworthy corroboration.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::statement against interest}} requires {{c2::declarant unavailable}}, {{c3::against pecuniary/proprietary/penal interest}}, {{c4::reasonable person wouldn’t say it unless true}}, and in criminal cases {{c5::corroborating circumstances}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 034. Dying Declarations
cards.backPlain: A hearsay statement is admissible if the declarant made the statement under the belief of impending death and the statement describes the cause or circumstances of the impending death. 1. Requirements for dying declaration (statement is admissible if): 1.1 Declarant is currently unavailable (death of the declarant is not required). 1.2 The out-of-court statement was made under the belief of impending death (the declarant must only have believed he was dying when the statement was made). 1.3 The statement was made regarding the cause or circumstances surrounding the belief of impending death. 2. The dying declaration exception is only available in: 2.1 Civil cases; and 2.2 Homicide cases.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for the hearsay exception for a dying declaration, and in what types of cases does it apply?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::hearsay}} statement is admissible if the declarant made the statement under the {{c2::belief of impending death}} and the statement describes the {{c3::cause or circumstances}} of the impending death. 1. Requirements for {{c4::dying declaration}} (statement is admissible if): 1.1 Declarant is currently {{c5::unavailable}} (death of the declarant is {{c6::not required}}). 1.2 The out-of-court statement was made under the {{c7::belief of impending death}} (the declarant must only have believed he was dying when the statement was made). 1.3 The statement was made regarding the {{c8::cause or circumstances}} surrounding the belief of impending death. 2. The dying declaration exception is only available in: 2.1 {{c9::Civil cases}}; and 2.2 {{c10::Homicide cases}}.
cards.easyContent: A dying declaration is admissible hearsay when a now-unavailable declarant, believing death was imminent, made a statement about the cause or circumstances of the impending death, and the case is a civil case or a homicide case.
cards.mediumContent: For a dying declaration, the declarant must be unavailable (but need not actually be dead), must have made the statement under a belief of impending death, and the statement must concern the cause or circumstances of that impending death; the exception only applies in civil cases and homicide prosecutions.
cards.hardContent: The dying declaration hearsay exception applies when: (1) the declarant is unavailable (though actual death is not required); (2) the statement was made while the declarant believed death was imminent; and (3) the statement concerns the cause or circumstances of the believed impending death. This exception is limited to civil cases and homicide cases.
cards.mnemonic: "I’m dying because…"—think imminent death, cause, civil or homicide.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::dying declaration}} requires an {{c2::unavailable declarant}} who {{c3::believes death is imminent}} and speaks about {{c4::cause or circumstances of death}} in {{c5::civil or homicide}} cases.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Present Sense Impression and Excited Utterance
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 035. Present Sense Impression and Excited Utterance
cards.front: Present Sense Impression and Excited Utterance
cards.backPlain: Present sense impression (a hearsay statement is admissible if it): 1. Describes or explains an event or condition; and 2. Is made contemporaneously with the event or immediately thereafter. 3. Timing is key: the statement must be made while, or immediately after, the declarant perceives the condition or event described in the statement. Excited utterance (a hearsay statement is admissible if it): 1. Relates to a startling or exciting event or condition; and 2. Was made while the declarant was under the stress or excitement of the event. 3. The declarant's emotional state is key: the declarant must be under such excitement or stress that one would not normally have an opportunity to fabricate the statement.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for the present sense impression and excited utterance hearsay exceptions?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Present sense impression}} (a hearsay statement is admissible if it): 1. {{c2::Describes or explains an event or condition}}; and 2. Is made {{c3::contemporaneously with the event or immediately thereafter}}. 3. {{c4::Timing is key}}: the statement must be made while, or immediately after, the declarant {{c5::perceives the condition or event}} described in the statement. {{c6::Excited utterance}} (a hearsay statement is admissible if it): 1. {{c7::Relates to a startling or exciting event or condition}}; and 2. Was made while the declarant was {{c8::under the stress or excitement of the event}}. 3. The declarant's {{c9::emotional state is key}}: the declarant must be under such excitement or stress that one would not normally have an {{c10::opportunity to fabricate}} the statement.
cards.easyContent: A present sense impression is a statement describing an event made as it happens or immediately after; an excited utterance is a statement about a startling event made while the declarant is still under the stress of that event.
cards.mediumContent: Present sense impression requires that the hearsay statement describe or explain an event or condition and be made while or immediately after the declarant perceives it. Excited utterance requires that the statement relate to a startling event and be made while the declarant is under the stress or excitement of that event, leaving no time to fabricate.
cards.hardContent: Under the present sense impression exception, a hearsay statement is admissible if it describes or explains an event or condition and is made contemporaneously with the event or immediately thereafter, while the declarant is perceiving it. Under the excited utterance exception, the statement must relate to a startling or exciting event or condition and must be made while the declarant is still under the stress or excitement of that event, such that there is no normal opportunity to fabricate.
cards.mnemonic: "Present" = sensing now; "Excited" = startling event while still shaken.
cards.clozeLite: Present sense impression: {{c1::describe or explain an event}} {{c2::while or immediately after perceiving it}}. Excited utterance: {{c3::relates to a startling event}} {{c4::while under its stress or excitement}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Statement Concerning Present State of Mind or Condition
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 036. Statement Concerning Present State of Mind or Condition
cards.front: Statement Concerning Present State of Mind or Condition
cards.backPlain: Hearsay statements are admissible if they concern a declarant's state of mind, emotion, sensation, or physical condition existing at the time the statement was made. 1. Statement of then-existing state of mind: 1.1 Usually offered to show a declarant's intent at the time the statement was made or as a circumstantial inference that the declarant's intent was likely carried out. 1.2 Distinguish from statements offered as circumstantial evidence of the declarant's state of mind, which are not hearsay. 1.3 Statements of intent may be admissible as circumstantial evidence tending to show that an act was committed at a later time. 2. Statement of then-existing condition: 2.1 Usually offered to establish some physical condition, symptom, or sensation that the declarant experienced at the time of the statement. Items to note: 1. The statement must concern a then-existing condition or mental state. 2. Statements of memory or belief are inadmissible because they do not reflect on a then-existing condition.
cards.frontPrompt: When are statements concerning a declarant’s present state of mind or physical condition admissible as a hearsay exception, and what important limitations apply?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Hearsay}} statements are admissible if they concern a declarant's {{c2::state of mind, emotion, sensation, or physical condition}} existing at the time the statement was made. 1. Statement of {{c3::then-existing state of mind}}: 1.1 Usually offered to show a declarant's {{c4::intent}} at the time the statement was made or as a circumstantial inference that the declarant's intent was likely carried out. 1.2 Distinguish from statements offered as {{c5::circumstantial evidence of the declarant's state of mind}}, which are {{c6::not hearsay}}. 1.3 Statements of intent may be admissible as circumstantial evidence tending to show that an act was committed at a later time. 2. Statement of {{c7::then-existing condition}}: 2.1 Usually offered to establish some {{c8::physical condition, symptom, or sensation}} that the declarant experienced at the time of the statement. Items to note: 1. The statement must concern a {{c9::then-existing condition or mental state}}. 2. Statements of {{c10::memory or belief}} are inadmissible because they do not reflect on a then-existing condition.
cards.easyContent: Statements describing a declarant’s then-existing state of mind or physical condition are admissible hearsay to show that state, but not to prove past facts remembered or believed.
cards.mediumContent: The present state-of-mind/condition exception allows hearsay statements about a declarant’s then-existing mental, emotional, or physical condition, often to show intent (which may be inferred as carried out) or current symptoms. The statement must concern a current condition, not past events, and statements of memory or belief are excluded because they do not reflect a then-existing condition.
cards.hardContent: Under the present state-of-mind/condition hearsay exception, statements that directly describe the declarant’s then-existing mental, emotional, or physical condition (including intent, plan, pain, or symptoms) are admissible to prove that condition and may serve as circumstantial evidence that an intended act occurred later. This must be distinguished from statements offered merely as circumstantial evidence of state of mind, which are not hearsay at all. The key limitation is that the statement must concern a then-existing condition or mental state; statements of memory or belief about past events are inadmissible under this exception because they do not reflect a current condition.
cards.mnemonic: "How I feel now" in; "what I remember then" out.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::present state-of-mind/condition}} exception covers {{c2::then-existing mental, emotional, or physical condition}} but excludes {{c3::statements of memory or belief about past events}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Statement of Physical Condition for Diagnosis or Treatment
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 037. Statement of Physical Condition for Diagnosis or Treatment
cards.front: Statement of Physical Condition for Diagnosis or Treatment
cards.backPlain: Statements regarding physical condition are admissible if made to medical personnel for the purpose of diagnosis or treatment. 1. Requirements: 1.1 Statement must be made to medical personnel (includes anyone involved in treatment or diagnosis; not necessarily a doctor). 1.2 Statement must be pertinent to assisting in the diagnosis or treatment of a condition. 1.2.1 Related statements (such as an admission) about an injury-causing event are usually inadmissible. 1.2.2 Example: a statement by the declarant to an emergency room doctor that she was shot will be admissible, but the identity of the shooter will not, as it is not pertinent to treatment. 1.3 Distinguish from statements of then-existing physical condition: statements concerning then-existing (i.e., contemporaneous) physical condition are admissible regardless of whether they are made to medical personnel.
cards.frontPrompt: When is a statement about a person’s physical condition admissible under the hearsay exception for statements made for purposes of medical diagnosis or treatment, and how does this differ from the then-existing physical condition exception?
cards.cloze: Statements regarding {{c1::physical condition}} are admissible if made to {{c2::medical personnel}} for the purpose of {{c3::diagnosis or treatment}}. 1. Requirements: 1.1 Statement must be made to medical personnel (includes anyone involved in {{c4::treatment or diagnosis}}; not necessarily a doctor). 1.2 Statement must be {{c5::pertinent to assisting in the diagnosis or treatment}} of a condition. 1.2.1 Related statements (such as an {{c6::admission}}) about an {{c7::injury-causing event}} are usually inadmissible. 1.2.2 Example: a statement by the declarant to an {{c8::emergency room doctor}} that she was shot will be admissible, but the {{c9::identity of the shooter}} will not, as it is not pertinent to treatment. 1.3 Distinguish from statements of {{c10::then-existing physical condition}}: statements concerning then-existing (i.e., contemporaneous) physical condition are admissible regardless of whether they are made to medical personnel.
cards.easyContent: A statement describing a person’s physical condition is admissible if it is made to medical personnel for purposes of diagnosis or treatment and is pertinent to that care.
cards.mediumContent: Statements about physical condition are admissible if made to medical personnel (anyone involved in diagnosis or treatment) and if they are pertinent to diagnosing or treating the condition. Details about how an injury occurred that are not relevant to treatment (like the shooter’s identity) are usually inadmissible. By contrast, then-existing physical condition statements are admissible regardless of being made to medical personnel.
cards.hardContent: Statements regarding physical condition are admissible if made to medical personnel for the purpose of diagnosis or treatment. The requirements are: (1) the statement must be made to medical personnel, which includes anyone involved in treatment or diagnosis, not necessarily a doctor; and (2) the statement must be pertinent to assisting in the diagnosis or treatment of a condition. Related statements, such as admissions about an injury-causing event, are usually inadmissible if they do not help with treatment. For example, a statement that the declarant was shot is admissible, but identifying the shooter is not because it is not pertinent to treatment. Distinguish this from the then-existing physical condition exception, under which statements about a contemporaneous physical condition are admissible regardless of whether they are made to medical personnel.
cards.mnemonic: DOC TREAT: to medical DOC, helps TREAT or diagnose.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::statement about physical condition}} is admissible if made {{c2::to medical personnel}} {{c3::for diagnosis or treatment}} and {{c4::pertinent to that care}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 038. Business Records
cards.backPlain: 1. Requirements (hearsay statements in the form of business records are admissible if they are): 1.1 A record of an act, event, condition, opinion, or diagnosis made or recorded by a business (for example, receipts, reports, patient records). 1.2 Made in the regular course of business (i.e., as a regular practice). 1.3 Made by, or from information transmitted by, someone with knowledge, at or near the time of the matters described. 1.4 Authenticated or certified in writing. 1.4.1 Trustworthiness: the court may exclude an otherwise qualifying record if circumstances indicate a lack of trustworthiness. 1.4.2 Absence of record: records meeting these requirements may be admitted to show that a matter did not occur or exist. 2. Police reports: in criminal cases, police reports or other criminal investigative reports are inadmissible against the defendant as business records or public records. 3. Multiple hearsay issues: 3.1 Business records often involve multiple layers of hearsay. 3.2 Every layer must fall into some exception or exemption to be admissible. 3.3 Example: minutes of a business meeting with a secretary's notes of participants' statements; the secretary's notes are one level of hearsay, and the participants' statements are another.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for admitting a business record under the hearsay exception, how are trustworthiness and absence of a record treated, and how do police reports and multiple hearsay affect admissibility?
cards.cloze: 1. Requirements ({{c1::hearsay statements in the form of business records}} are admissible if they are): 1.1 A {{c2::record of an act, event, condition, opinion, or diagnosis}} made or recorded by a business (for example, receipts, reports, patient records). 1.2 Made in the {{c3::regular course of business}} (i.e., as a regular practice). 1.3 Made by, or from information transmitted by, {{c4::someone with knowledge}}, at or near the {{c5::time of the matters described}}. 1.4 {{c6::Authenticated or certified in writing}}. 1.4.1 {{c7::Trustworthiness}}: the court may exclude an otherwise qualifying record if circumstances indicate a lack of trustworthiness. 1.4.2 {{c8::Absence of record}}: records meeting these requirements may be admitted to show that a matter {{c9::did not occur or exist}}. 2. {{c10::Police reports}}: in criminal cases, police reports or other criminal investigative reports are {{c11::inadmissible against the defendant}} as business records or public records. 3. {{c12::Multiple hearsay}} issues: 3.1 Business records often involve {{c13::multiple layers of hearsay}}. 3.2 Every layer must fall into some {{c14::exception or exemption}} to be admissible. 3.3 Example: minutes of a business meeting with a {{c15::secretary's notes of participants' statements}}; the secretary's notes are one level of hearsay, and the participants' statements are another.
cards.easyContent: A business record is admissible if it is a record of an act, event, condition, opinion, or diagnosis made in the regular course of business, by someone with knowledge at or near the time, and properly authenticated, unless circumstances show it is untrustworthy.
cards.mediumContent: Business records are admissible hearsay if: (1) they are records of acts, events, conditions, opinions, or diagnoses made or kept by a business; (2) made in the regular course of business as a regular practice; (3) made by, or from information transmitted by, someone with knowledge at or near the time; and (4) authenticated or certified. The court may exclude a record if it appears untrustworthy. A qualifying record can also prove that a matter did not occur or exist when the record is absent. In criminal cases, police and criminal investigative reports are not admissible against the defendant as business or public records. Because business records often contain multiple levels of hearsay, each level must fit an exception or exemption.
cards.hardContent: Hearsay statements in the form of business records are admissible if they are: (1) a record of an act, event, condition, opinion, or diagnosis made or recorded by a business (such as receipts, reports, and patient records); (2) made in the regular course of business as a regular practice; (3) made by, or from information transmitted by, someone with knowledge, at or near the time of the matters described; and (4) authenticated or certified in writing. Even if these elements are met, the court may exclude the record if the source or circumstances indicate a lack of trustworthiness. Business records that meet these requirements may also be used to show the absence of an entry as evidence that a matter did not occur or exist. In criminal cases, police reports or other criminal investigative reports are inadmissible against the defendant as business records or public records. Because business records often contain multiple layers of hearsay (for example, a secretary’s minutes of participants’ statements at a meeting), each layer must independently fall within a hearsay exception or exemption to be admitted.
cards.mnemonic: ROUTINE KNOWLEDGE RECORD: Regular, Knowledge, near Time, Recorded.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::business record}} is admissible hearsay if made in the {{c2::regular course of business}} by someone with {{c3::knowledge}} {{c4::at or near the time}} and {{c5::properly authenticated or certified}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Public Records, Judgments, and Prior Convictions
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 039. Public Records, Judgments, and Prior Convictions
cards.front: Public Records, Judgments, and Prior Convictions
cards.backPlain: 1. Public records (a public office or agency record is admissible if it): 1.1 Describes the activities of a public office or agency. 1.2 Describes either: 1.2.1 Matters observed pursuant to a duty imposed by law, or 1.2.2 Factual findings resulting from an investigation made pursuant to authority granted by law. 1.3 Is made by a public employee within the scope of their duty. 1.4 Is made at or near the time of the event. 2. Exception (criminal cases): in criminal cases, police records or other criminal investigative reports are inadmissible against the defendant as public records. 3. Trustworthiness required: the court may exclude an otherwise qualifying public record if the source of information or other circumstances indicate a lack of trustworthiness. 4. Absence of public record: certification or testimony from a public official that a diligent search failed to find a record is admissible to: 4.1 Prove that the record does not exist, or 4.2 Prove that a matter did not occur (if records were kept regularly). 5. Judgments and prior convictions: 5.1 Judgments: certified copies are admissible in both civil and criminal cases to prove any fact essential to the judgment. 5.2 Prior convictions: prior convictions are generally inadmissible in criminal cases against non-defendants unless used for impeachment.
cards.frontPrompt: When is a public record admissible under the hearsay exception, what limits apply in criminal cases, how can the absence of a record be used, and how are judgments and prior convictions treated?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Public records}} (a public office or agency record is admissible if it): 1.1 Describes the {{c2::activities of a public office or agency}}. 1.2 Describes either: 1.2.1 {{c3::Matters observed}} pursuant to a {{c4::duty imposed by law}}, or 1.2.2 {{c5::Factual findings}} resulting from an {{c6::investigation made pursuant to authority granted by law}}. 1.3 Is made by a {{c7::public employee}} within the scope of their duty. 1.4 Is made at or near the {{c8::time of the event}}. 2. {{c9::Exception (criminal cases)}}: in criminal cases, police records or other criminal investigative reports are {{c10::inadmissible against the defendant}} as public records. 3. {{c11::Trustworthiness required}}: the court may exclude an otherwise qualifying public record if the source of information or other circumstances indicate a lack of trustworthiness. 4. {{c12::Absence of public record}}: certification or testimony from a public official that a {{c13::diligent search}} failed to find a record is admissible to: 4.1 Prove that the {{c14::record does not exist}}, or 4.2 Prove that a {{c15::matter did not occur}} (if records were kept regularly). 5. {{c16::Judgments and prior convictions}}: 5.1 Judgments: {{c17::certified copies}} are admissible in both civil and criminal cases to prove any {{c18::fact essential to the judgment}}. 5.2 Prior convictions: prior convictions are generally {{c19::inadmissible in criminal cases against non-defendants}} unless used for {{c20::impeachment}}.
cards.easyContent: Public records are admissible if they describe government activities, matters observed under a legal duty, or factual findings from authorized investigations, made by a public employee at or near the time, unless untrustworthy or barred in criminal cases as to the defendant.
cards.mediumContent: A public office or agency record is admissible if it (1) describes the activities of the office or agency; (2) describes matters observed pursuant to a legal duty or factual findings from an investigation made under legal authority; (3) is made by a public employee within the scope of duty; and (4) is made at or near the time of the event. In criminal cases, police and other criminal investigative reports are inadmissible against the defendant as public records. The court may always exclude a public record that appears untrustworthy. The absence of a public record, proven by a public official’s certification or testimony after a diligent search, can be used to show that a record does not exist or that an event did not occur where records are regularly kept. Certified copies of judgments are admissible in civil and criminal cases to prove facts essential to the judgment; prior convictions are generally inadmissible in criminal cases against non-defendants except for impeachment.
cards.hardContent: Under the public records hearsay exception, a record of a public office or agency is admissible if it (1) describes the activities of the office or agency; (2) describes either matters observed pursuant to a duty imposed by law or factual findings resulting from an investigation made pursuant to authority granted by law; (3) is made by a public employee within the scope of their duty; and (4) is made at or near the time of the event. However, in criminal cases, police records and other criminal investigative reports are inadmissible against the defendant as public records. In all cases, the court may exclude an otherwise qualifying public record if the source of information or other circumstances indicate a lack of trustworthiness. The absence of a public record can be proved by a public official’s certification or testimony that a diligent search failed to find the record, which is admissible to prove that the record does not exist or that a matter did not occur when such matters are regularly recorded. Finally, certified copies of judgments are admissible in both civil and criminal cases to prove any fact essential to the judgment, while prior convictions are generally inadmissible in criminal cases against non-defendants unless offered for impeachment.
cards.mnemonic: "GOV FACTS": Government office Activities, duty Observations, investigative Findings, Employee on Time, unless untrustworthy.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::public record}} is admissible if it describes {{c2::agency activities}}, {{c3::duty-based observations}} or {{c4::investigative factual findings}}, unless {{c5::untrustworthy}} or {{c6::barred in criminal cases against the defendant}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 040. Miscellaneous Hearsay Exceptions
cards.backPlain: 1. Learned treatises: 1.1 Arises with expert testimony only. 1.2 Learned treatises are accepted authority in a given field. 1.3 They must be established as reliable and accepted authority by testimony, admission, or judicial notice. 1.4 Experts can rely on learned treatises on direct examination or can be impeached with information from treatises on cross-examination. 1.5 If admissible, statements from learned treatises may only be read into evidence (not received as exhibits). 2. Family records: statements of fact found in family keepsakes (for example, jewelry engravings, family Bibles, genealogies). 3. Ancient documents: an authenticated document prepared before January 1, 1998, used to prove the truth of its contents.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the hearsay exceptions for learned treatises, family records, and ancient documents, and how are learned treatises used with expert testimony?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Learned treatises}}: 1.1 Arises with {{c2::expert testimony only}}. 1.2 Learned treatises are {{c3::accepted authority in a given field}}. 1.3 They must be established as {{c4::reliable and accepted authority}} by {{c5::testimony, admission, or judicial notice}}. 1.4 Experts can {{c6::rely on learned treatises on direct examination}} or can be {{c7::impeached with information from treatises on cross-examination}}. 1.5 If admissible, statements from learned treatises may only be {{c8::read into evidence}} (not received as exhibits). 2. {{c9::Family records}}: statements of fact found in family keepsakes (for example, jewelry engravings, family Bibles, genealogies). 3. {{c10::Ancient documents}}: an {{c11::authenticated document}} prepared {{c12::before January 1, 1998}}, used to prove the {{c13::truth of its contents}}.
cards.easyContent: Learned treatises, family records, and ancient documents are special hearsay exceptions; learned treatises support or impeach expert testimony and are read to the jury, while family records and qualifying ancient documents are admissible for the truth of their contents.
cards.mediumContent: Learned treatises are writings that are accepted authority in a field and arise only with expert testimony. They must be shown reliable and authoritative by testimony, admission, or judicial notice. An expert can rely on them on direct, and an opposing party can use them to impeach on cross; if admitted, passages are read into evidence but the treatise itself is not an exhibit. Family records are statements of fact found in family keepsakes, such as jewelry engravings, family Bibles, or genealogies. Ancient documents are authenticated documents prepared before January 1, 1998, and may be used to prove the truth of their contents.
cards.hardContent: Miscellaneous hearsay exceptions include learned treatises, family records, and ancient documents. Learned treatises arise only in connection with expert testimony. A learned treatise is an accepted authority in a given field and must be established as reliable and authoritative by testimony, admission, or judicial notice. Experts may rely on learned treatises on direct examination, and opposing counsel may use them to impeach an expert on cross-examination. When admissible, statements from a learned treatise may be read into evidence but the treatise itself is not admitted as an exhibit. The family records exception covers statements of fact found in family keepsakes, such as jewelry engravings, entries in family Bibles, and genealogies. The ancient documents exception allows admission of an authenticated document prepared before January 1, 1998, to prove the truth of its contents.
cards.mnemonic: TFA-98: Treatises, Family records, Ancient docs before 1998.
cards.clozeLite: Misc. hearsay exceptions: {{c1::learned treatises}} (used with {{c2::expert testimony}} and {{c3::read into evidence only}}), {{c4::family records}}, and {{c5::ancient documents (pre-1/1/1998)}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 041. Confrontation Clause
cards.backPlain: An otherwise admissible out-of-court statement offered against the defendant in a criminal case may be excluded under the Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause. 1. An out-of-court statement offered against the defendant will be excluded if: 1.1 The declarant is currently unavailable. 1.2 The defendant had no prior opportunity to cross-examine the declarant about the statement. 1.3 The statement is testimonial. 1.4 Exception: an out-of-court statement will not be excluded if the declarant is unavailable as a result of the defendant's own wrongdoing (forfeiture by wrongdoing). 2. Testimonial statements include: 2.1 Prior statements made during court proceedings. 2.2 Statements made in furtherance of a police investigation (for example, a statement aimed at producing evidence potentially relevant to a later prosecution). 2.3 Business records are not generally considered testimonial. 2.4 Exception: statements made to police during an ongoing emergency are non-testimonial and can be admitted without violating the Confrontation Clause.
cards.frontPrompt: When does the Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause bar admission of an out-of-court statement in a criminal case, what counts as a testimonial statement, and what is the forfeiture-by-wrongdoing and ongoing-emergency exception?
cards.cloze: An otherwise admissible {{c1::out-of-court statement}} offered against the {{c2::defendant in a criminal case}} may be excluded under the {{c3::Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause}}. 1.
