An out-of-court statement offered against the defendant will be excluded if: 1.1 The {{c4::declarant is currently unavailable}}. 1.2 The defendant had {{c5::no prior opportunity to cross-examine}} the declarant about the statement. 1.3 The statement is {{c6::testimonial}}. 1.4 Exception: an out-of-court statement will not be excluded if the declarant is unavailable as a result of the defendant's own wrongdoing ({{c7::forfeiture by wrongdoing}}). 2. {{c8::Testimonial}} statements include: 2.1 Prior statements made during {{c9::court proceedings}}. 2.2 Statements made in furtherance of a {{c10::police investigation}} (for example, a statement aimed at producing evidence potentially relevant to a later prosecution). 2.3 {{c11::Business records}} are not generally considered testimonial. 2.4 Exception: statements made to police during an {{c12::ongoing emergency}} are {{c13::non-testimonial}} and can be admitted without violating the Confrontation Clause.
cards.easyContent: In a criminal case, testimonial out-of-court statements against the defendant are barred by the Confrontation Clause if the declarant is unavailable and the defendant had no prior chance to cross‑examine, unless the defendant caused the unavailability.
cards.mediumContent: The Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause can exclude an otherwise admissible out-of-court statement offered against a criminal defendant when: (1) the declarant is unavailable; (2) the defendant had no prior opportunity to cross-examine the declarant about the statement; and (3) the statement is testimonial. Testimonial statements include prior statements during court proceedings and statements to police made to create evidence for later prosecution. Business records are generally non-testimonial. If the defendant wrongfully causes the declarant’s unavailability (forfeiture by wrongdoing), the defendant forfeits Confrontation Clause protection. Statements to police during an ongoing emergency are non-testimonial and may be admitted without violating the Clause.
cards.hardContent: Under the Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause, an otherwise admissible out-of-court statement offered against the defendant in a criminal case must be excluded when: (1) the declarant is currently unavailable; (2) the defendant had no prior opportunity to cross-examine the declarant about the statement; and (3) the statement is testimonial in nature. Testimonial statements include prior testimony or statements made during court proceedings, and statements made in furtherance of a police investigation when the primary purpose is to produce evidence for a later prosecution. Business records are generally not considered testimonial. There are important exceptions: if the declarant is unavailable as a result of the defendant’s own wrongdoing, the defendant forfeits the right to confront that witness (forfeiture by wrongdoing), and the statement may be admitted. Additionally, statements made to police during an ongoing emergency are treated as non-testimonial and can be admitted without violating the Confrontation Clause.
cards.mnemonic: UTC + FOE: Unavailable, no prior cross, Testimonial; Forfeiture or Ongoing Emergency allow Entry.
cards.clozeLite: Confrontation bars {{c1::testimonial}} statements when {{c2::declarant is unavailable}} and {{c3::no prior cross-exam}}—unless {{c4::forfeiture by wrongdoing}} or {{c5::ongoing emergency}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 042. Co Defendant Statements
cards.backPlain: 1. Confrontation Clause rule 1.1 The Confrontation Clause bars admission, at a joint trial, of an out-of-court statement by a non-testifying co-defendant if the statement expressly implicates another defendant. 2. Exceptions (a co-defendant's out-of-court statement is admissible if either condition is met) 2.1 Declarant co-defendant testifies: The Confrontation Clause does not bar an out-of-court statement if the declarant co-defendant testifies at trial and is subject to cross-examination. 2.2 Redaction: The statement may be admitted if all portions referring to the non-declarant defendant are effectively redacted so that the non-declarant co-defendant's identity is truly anonymous. 2.3 Coerced confession rebuttal: The statement may be admitted when it is used solely to rebut a charge that the defendant's own confession was coerced.
cards.frontPrompt: When does the Confrontation Clause bar admission of a non-testifying co-defendant’s out-of-court statement at a joint trial, and what are the main exceptions?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Confrontation Clause}} rule 1.1 The {{c1::Confrontation Clause}} bars admission, at a {{c2::joint trial}}, of an {{c3::out-of-court statement}} by a {{c4::non-testifying co-defendant}} if the statement {{c5::expressly implicates another defendant}}. 2. {{c6::Exceptions}} (a co-defendant's out-of-court statement is admissible if either condition is met) 2.1 {{c7::Declarant co-defendant testifies}}: The Confrontation Clause does not bar an out-of-court statement if the declarant co-defendant {{c8::testifies at trial and is subject to cross-examination}}. 2.2 {{c9::Redaction}}: The statement may be admitted if all portions referring to the non-declarant defendant are effectively redacted so that the non-declarant co-defendant's {{c10::identity is truly anonymous}}. 2.3 {{c11::Coerced confession rebuttal}}: The statement may be admitted when it is used solely to {{c12::rebut a charge that the defendant's own confession was coerced}}.
cards.easyContent: At a joint trial, the Confrontation Clause generally bars admitting an out-of-court statement by a non-testifying co-defendant that expressly implicates another defendant. It can come in if the declarant co-defendant testifies and is subject to cross, if the statement is effectively redacted to hide the other defendant’s identity, or if used only to rebut a coerced-confession claim.
cards.mediumContent: The Confrontation Clause bars admission, at a joint trial, of an out-of-court statement by a non-testifying co-defendant when it expressly implicates another defendant. The statement may be admitted if: (1) the declarant co-defendant testifies at trial and is subject to cross-examination; (2) the statement is effectively redacted so that the other defendant’s identity is truly anonymous; or (3) it is used solely to rebut a charge that the defendant’s own confession was coerced.
cards.hardContent: The Confrontation Clause prohibits, at a joint criminal trial, the admission of an out-of-court statement by a non-testifying co-defendant that expressly implicates another defendant. This bar is lifted if: (1) the declarant co-defendant testifies at trial and is subject to full cross-examination about the statement; (2) the statement is redacted so that all references to the non-declarant defendant are removed or neutralized, and the identity of the non-declarant is truly anonymous; or (3) the statement is introduced solely to rebut a claim that the defendant’s own confession was coerced, rather than for its truth as to the co-defendant’s guilt.
cards.mnemonic: J-R-C: Joint trial bar; Joins stand, Redacted, Coerced-confession rebuttal.
cards.clozeLite: At a {{c1::joint trial}}, the {{c2::Confrontation Clause}} bars a {{c3::non-testifying co-defendant’s statement}} that {{c4::expressly implicates another defendant}}, unless {{c5::declarant testifies, effective redaction, or rebutting coerced-confession claim}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 003-1. Public Policy Exclusions – Liability Insurance
cards.frontPrompt: How does the public policy rule treat evidence of liability insurance, and for what purposes can it and can’t it be used?
cards.backPlain: Liability insurance 1. Evidence of liability insurance is not admissible to prove fault or a party's ability to pay damages. 2. Evidence of insurance is admissible to prove other matters, such as ownership, control, or motive.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Liability insurance}} 1. Evidence of liability insurance is {{c2::not admissible}} to prove {{c3::fault or a party's ability to pay damages}}. 2. Evidence of insurance is admissible to prove other matters, such as {{c4::ownership, control, or motive}}.
cards.easyContent: Evidence that someone has liability insurance cannot be used to prove they were at fault or could pay a judgment, but it can be used to show things like ownership, control, or motive.
cards.mediumContent: On public policy grounds, evidence of liability insurance is inadmissible to prove that a party was negligent or otherwise at fault, or that the party has the ability to pay damages. However, the same evidence may be admitted for other relevant purposes, such as showing ownership or control of property or a vehicle, or establishing motive (e.g., evidence of lack of insurance to show motive to flee).
cards.hardContent: Evidence of liability insurance is excluded on public policy grounds to avoid discouraging people from carrying insurance and to prevent unfair prejudice. It is inadmissible when offered to prove fault (e.g., negligence, wrongdoing) or a party's ability to pay a judgment. However, such evidence may be admissible for other relevant, non-fault purposes, including: (1) ownership of the property or instrumentality involved in the incident; (2) control over the premises or instrumentality; and (3) motive (for example, to explain why a defendant might have acted in a certain way). When admitted for these limited purposes, a limiting instruction may be appropriate.
cards.mnemonic: Insurance: no FAP—no Fault or Ability to Pay.
cards.clozeLite: Liability insurance is {{c1::inadmissible to prove fault or ability to pay}}, but {{c2::admissible to show ownership, control, or motive}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Public Policy Exclusions – Subsequent Remedial Measures
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 003-2. Public Policy Exclusions – Subsequent Remedial Measures
cards.front: Public Policy Exclusions – Subsequent Remedial Measures
cards.frontPrompt: How are subsequent remedial measures treated under the public policy exclusions, and what are the main exceptions?
cards.backPlain: Subsequent remedial measures 1. Evidence of repairs or other remedial measures taken after an injury is inadmissible to prove fault, a defective product or design, or an inadequate warning. 2. Evidence of subsequent remedial measures is admissible to rebut a claim or defense that there was no feasible precaution or to prove ownership or control when disputed.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Subsequent remedial measures}} 1. Evidence of repairs or other remedial measures taken after an injury is {{c2::inadmissible}} to prove {{c3::fault, a defective product or design, or an inadequate warning}}. 2. The same evidence is {{c4::admissible}} to {{c5::rebut a claim or defense that there was no feasible precaution}} or to prove {{c6::ownership or control}} when those issues are disputed.
cards.easyContent: Repairs or safety changes made after an accident can’t be used to prove fault, defect, or an inadequate warning, but they can be used to show ownership or control or to rebut a claim that no safer alternative was feasible.
cards.mediumContent: Evidence of subsequent remedial measures—such as repairs or design changes made after an injury—cannot be used to prove that the defendant was negligent, at fault, or that a product or warning was defective. The policy is to encourage repairs without fear they will be used against the defendant. However, if ownership or control of the property or instrumentality is disputed, subsequent repairs can be used to show ownership or control. Likewise, if a party claims there was no feasible safer alternative, evidence of later remedial measures may be admitted to rebut that claim.
cards.hardContent: Subsequent remedial measures are steps taken after an injury or harm to make an event less likely to occur again, such as repairs, design changes, additional warnings, or new policies. On public policy grounds, this evidence is inadmissible when offered to prove that the party was negligent or otherwise at fault, that a product or design was defective, or that a warning was inadequate. The policy is to encourage prompt repairs and safety improvements without fear of those fixes being used as admissions of fault. However, the rule is not absolute. Evidence of subsequent remedial measures may be admitted for other purposes, including: (1) proving ownership or control of the property or instrumentality, when those issues are disputed; and (2) rebutting a claim or defense that there was no feasible precaution or safer alternative design. When used for these permissible purposes, a limiting instruction is often appropriate.
cards.mnemonic: No Fault from Fixes: later repairs show control or feasibility, not fault.
cards.clozeLite: Evidence of {{c1::subsequent remedial measures}} can’t prove {{c2::negligence or defect}}, but may show {{c3::ownership or control}} or {{c4::feasible safer alternative}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Public Policy Exclusions – Settlements and Plea Bargaining
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 003-3. Public Policy Exclusions – Settlements and Plea Bargaining
cards.front: Public Policy Exclusions – Settlements and Plea Bargaining
cards.frontPrompt: How are civil settlement discussions and criminal plea discussions treated under the public policy exclusions, and what are key limits on the protection?
cards.backPlain: Settlements, offers to settle, and plea bargaining 1. Civil cases: Compromises, settlement offers, and related statements (including factual admissions) about a disputed claim are inadmissible to prove liability, fault, or the amount of a disputed claim. 2. This civil rule does not apply to statements made before a claim was asserted or before there was a threat of litigation. 3. Criminal cases: Pleas, offers to plead, and related statements (including factual admissions) are inadmissible to prove guilt or the amount of punishment.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Settlements, offers to settle, and plea bargaining}} 1. In {{c2::civil cases}}, compromises, settlement offers, and related statements (including factual admissions) about a {{c3::disputed claim}} are {{c4::inadmissible}} to prove {{c5::liability, fault, or the amount of a disputed claim}}. 2. This rule does not apply to statements made {{c6::before a claim was asserted or before there was a threat of litigation}}. 3. In {{c7::criminal cases}}, pleas, offers to plead, and related statements (including factual admissions) are {{c8::inadmissible}} to prove {{c9::guilt or the amount of punishment}}.
cards.easyContent: Settlement offers and related statements about a disputed civil claim, and criminal pleas and plea discussions, can’t be used to prove liability, fault, the amount of a civil claim, guilt, or punishment. The protection generally applies only once there is a dispute or actual plea discussion.
cards.mediumContent: To encourage settlement and plea bargaining, evidence law excludes: (1) civil compromises, settlement offers, and related statements about a disputed claim when offered to prove liability, fault, or the amount of the claim; and (2) criminal pleas, offers to plead, and related statements when offered to prove guilt or punishment. For civil cases, the protection applies only once a claim has been asserted or there is a threat of litigation; statements made before any claim or threat are not covered. In both settings, the bar applies to both the offer itself and associated factual admissions, when offered for these forbidden purposes.
cards.hardContent: Settlements and plea bargaining are protected on public policy grounds to promote candid dispute resolution. Civil cases: • Compromises, settlement offers, and related statements, including factual admissions, concerning a disputed claim are inadmissible when offered to prove liability, fault, or the amount of the disputed claim. • The claim must be in dispute as to validity or amount. Statements made before any claim is asserted or before there is a threat of litigation are not covered by this exclusion and may be admissible under ordinary relevance rules. Criminal cases: • Pleas (such as nolo contendere or withdrawn guilty pleas), offers to plead, and related statements, including factual admissions made in the course of plea discussions with the prosecuting authority, are inadmissible when offered to prove guilt or the amount of punishment. In both civil and criminal contexts, the goal is to encourage frank negotiations and compromise without fear that statements made in those contexts will later be used as substantive evidence of liability, fault, guilt, or punishment.
cards.mnemonic: Dispute + Deal = Don’t Use for liability, fault, guilt, or amount.
cards.clozeLite: Evidence law excludes {{c1::civil settlement offers and related statements}} and {{c2::criminal pleas, offers, and related statements}} when offered to prove {{c3::liability, fault, amount, guilt, or punishment}}; civil protection applies only {{c4::once a claim is disputed or litigation is threatened}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Public Policy Exclusions – Payment of Medical Expenses
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 003-4. Public Policy Exclusions – Payment of Medical Expenses
cards.front: Public Policy Exclusions – Payment of Medical Expenses
cards.frontPrompt: How are payments or offers to pay medical expenses treated under the public policy exclusions, and how do related statements differ?
cards.backPlain: Payment or offers to pay medical expenses 1. Payment of, or offers to pay, medical expenses are inadmissible when offered to prove liability for the injuries. 2. Related statements, including factual admissions, are admissible unless another exclusionary rule applies. 3. Offers to pay medical expenses in exchange for a liability release are treated as settlement offers and are inadmissible to prove liability or the amount of a disputed claim.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Payment or offers to pay medical expenses}} 1. Payment of, or offers to pay, medical expenses are {{c2::inadmissible}} when offered to prove {{c3::liability for the injuries}}. 2. Related statements, including factual admissions, are {{c4::admissible}} unless {{c5::another exclusionary rule}} applies. 3. Offers to pay medical expenses in exchange for a {{c6::liability release}} are treated as {{c7::settlement offers}} and are {{c8::inadmissible}} to prove liability or the amount of a disputed claim.
cards.easyContent: Offers to pay someone’s medical bills can’t be used to prove liability, but any separate statements made at the same time usually can be used, unless they fall under another exclusion like the settlement rule.
cards.mediumContent: To encourage humanitarian gestures, evidence law makes payments of, or offers to pay, medical expenses inadmissible to prove liability for the injuries. Unlike settlement discussions, however, accompanying factual admissions (e.g., “I’m so sorry I ran the light; I’ll pay your hospital bills”) are generally admissible unless another rule like the settlement exclusion applies. If the offer to pay medical expenses is bundled with a request for a release of liability, it is treated as a settlement offer and excluded when offered to prove liability or the amount of a disputed claim.
cards.hardContent: On public policy grounds, payments of, or offers to pay, medical expenses are inadmissible when offered to prove liability for the injuries, so as not to discourage people from making humanitarian offers to help. The exclusion is narrow: it applies only to the payment or offer itself. Related statements, including factual admissions made in conjunction with the offer to pay medical expenses, are generally admissible as party admissions unless another exclusionary rule applies. For example, a statement like “I ran the red light; let me pay your hospital bills” would be admissible as to the admission of fault but not as to the offer to pay bills. If an offer to pay medical expenses is combined with a request for a liability release or other compromise terms (e.g., "I’ll pay your medical bills if you sign this release"), the combined offer is treated as a settlement offer. In that case, it is inadmissible to prove liability or the amount of a disputed claim under the settlement exclusion.
cards.mnemonic: Medical payments: “Bill, not Blame” — bill excluded, blame may come in.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Payments of or offers to pay medical expenses}} are inadmissible to {{c2::prove liability}}, but {{c3::accompanying factual admissions}} are generally {{c4::admissible}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Similar Occurrences – General Rule and Admissible Uses
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 004-1. Similar Occurrences – General Rule and Admissible Uses
cards.front: Similar Occurrences – General Rule and Admissible Uses
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule on similar occurrences 1.1 Evidence of prior similar occurrences concerning the time, event, or person in the present controversy is often inadmissible as irrelevant or as presenting an unfair risk of prejudice. 1.2 However, similar occurrences may be relevant and admissible for other, specific non-propensity purposes. 2. Common admissible uses of similar occurrences 2.1 Causation. 2.2 Prior accidents demonstrating: 2.2.1 A pattern of fraudulent claims; or 2.2.2 Pre-existing conditions. 2.3 Intent or absence of mistake. 2.4 To rebut a defense of impossibility. 2.5 Value (e.g., similar transactions can establish value). 2.6 Industry custom (e.g., to prove standard of care). 2.7 Business routine (e.g., to show that a particular event occurred).
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general rule about admissibility of prior similar occurrences, and for what specific purposes may such evidence be admitted?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule on similar occurrences}} 1.1 Evidence of prior similar occurrences concerning the time, event, or person in the present controversy is often inadmissible as {{c2::irrelevant or as presenting an unfair risk of prejudice}}. 1.2 However, similar occurrences may be relevant and admissible for other, specific non-propensity purposes. 2. {{c3::Common admissible uses of similar occurrences}} 2.1 {{c4::Causation}}. 2.2 Prior accidents demonstrating: 2.2.1 A pattern of {{c5::fraudulent claims}}; or 2.2.2 {{c6::Pre-existing conditions}}. 2.3 {{c7::Intent or absence of mistake}}. 2.4 To rebut a defense of {{c8::impossibility}}. 2.5 {{c9::Value}} (e.g., similar transactions can establish value). 2.6 {{c10::Industry custom}} (e.g., to prove standard of care). 2.7 {{c11::Business routine}} (e.g., to show that a particular event occurred).
cards.easyContent: Prior similar occurrences are usually inadmissible as irrelevant or too prejudicial, but they can be admitted for limited, non-propensity purposes like proving causation, patterns of fraudulent claims or pre-existing conditions, intent or absence of mistake, rebutting impossibility, establishing value, showing industry custom, or demonstrating a business routine.
cards.mediumContent: Evidence of prior similar occurrences concerning the time, event, or persons in the present dispute is generally excluded as irrelevant or unduly prejudicial. However, it may be admitted when offered for specific purposes: to prove causation; to show prior accidents demonstrating a pattern of fraudulent claims or pre-existing conditions; to establish intent or absence of mistake; to rebut a defense of impossibility; to establish value through similar transactions; to show industry custom and thus the standard of care; or to demonstrate a business routine that suggests a particular event occurred.
cards.hardContent: Evidence of prior similar occurrences relating to the time, event, or persons involved in the current case is commonly excluded as either irrelevant or as posing an unfair risk of prejudice, confusion, or waste of time. Nonetheless, such evidence may be admissible when it is probative of a specific, non-character issue, including: causation; prior accidents that reveal a pattern of fraudulent claims or that a plaintiff’s injury was due to a pre-existing condition; the presence or absence of intent or mistake; rebutting a claimed impossibility; establishing the value of property or services through similar transactions; demonstrating industry custom to prove a standard of care; or proving the existence of a business routine to suggest that a particular act or event occurred in accordance with that routine.
cards.mnemonic: C P I I V I B: Causation, Pattern/pre-existing, Intent, Impossibility, Value, Industry, Business.
cards.clozeLite: Prior similar occurrences are generally {{c1::excluded as irrelevant or unduly prejudicial}}, but may be admitted to show {{c2::causation}}, {{c3::intent or absence of mistake}}, {{c4::value through similar transactions}}, or {{c5::industry custom or business routine}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 004-2. Habit Evidence – Definition and Requirements
cards.backPlain: 1. Habit evidence – definition and use 1.1 A person's habit may be relevant and admissible to show that the person acted in conformity with that habit on a given occasion. 1.2 Habit is different from character evidence: it involves a regular response to a specific situation, not a general disposition. 2. Requirements for habit 2.1 Habit conduct must be highly specific and frequently repeated—i.e., a person's regular response to a specific set of circumstances. 2.2 Look for regular, instinctive, habitual conduct. 2.3 Example: Evidence that a person habitually goes down a particular stairwell two steps at a time may be admissible as circumstantial evidence that she did so at the time in question.
cards.frontPrompt: What is habit evidence, how does it differ from character evidence, and what are the requirements for conduct to qualify as a habit?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Habit evidence – definition and use}} 1.1 A person's {{c2::habit}} may be relevant and admissible to show that the person acted in conformity with that habit on a given occasion. 1.2 Habit is different from {{c3::character evidence}}: it involves a {{c4::regular response to a specific situation}}, not a general disposition. 2. {{c5::Requirements for habit}} 2.1 Habit conduct must be {{c6::highly specific and frequently repeated}}—i.e., a person's regular response to a specific set of circumstances. 2.2 Look for {{c7::regular, instinctive, habitual conduct}}. 2.3 Example: Evidence that a person habitually goes down a particular stairwell two steps at a time may be admissible as circumstantial evidence that she did so at the time in question.
cards.easyContent: Habit evidence is proof of a person’s specific, frequently repeated behavior in a particular situation, used to show that they likely acted the same way on the occasion in question. It must be highly specific, regularly repeated conduct and is distinct from broad character evidence.
cards.mediumContent: Habit evidence is admissible to show that a person acted in conformity with that habit on a given occasion. It concerns a person’s regular response to a specific set of circumstances, not a general character trait. For conduct to qualify as habit, it must be highly specific and frequently repeated, indicating a regular, almost automatic pattern of behavior—for example, always descending a particular stairwell two steps at a time.
cards.hardContent: Habit evidence is a category of circumstantial evidence that allows the factfinder to infer that a person acted in the same way on the occasion at issue as they routinely do in a particular situation. Unlike character evidence, which reflects broad traits or dispositions, habit involves a regular, semi-automatic response to a narrowly defined set of circumstances. To qualify as habit, the conduct must be highly specific and frequently repeated, such that it reflects a regular, instinctive practice—e.g., a person who habitually descends a specific stairwell two steps at a time, allowing an inference that she likely did so at the time in question.
cards.mnemonic: Habit = SFR: Specific, Frequently repeated, Regular response.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Habit evidence}} shows a person’s {{c2::regular response to a specific situation}} and is {{c3::highly specific and frequently repeated}}, unlike {{c4::broad character evidence}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Impeachment – Contradiction vs Prior Inconsistent Statements (Basics)
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 012-1. Impeachment – Contradiction vs Prior Inconsistent Statements (Basics)
cards.front: Impeachment – Contradiction vs Prior Inconsistent Statements (Basics)
cards.backPlain: 1. Impeachment by contradiction 1.1 Any evidence may be used to show that the witness (W) has made contradictory statements on **material issues**. 1.2 The goal is to undermine W’s credibility by demonstrating inconsistency with prior statements or other evidence on important points. 2. Impeachment by prior inconsistent statement (PIS) 2.1 A prior inconsistent statement is a statement by W, made before trial, that conflicts with W’s present testimony. 2.2 W’s prior inconsistent statements may be used to impeach W’s present testimony by showing that W has changed or contradicted their story. 2.3 PIS is a specific form of contradiction focused on W’s own prior words, rather than other evidence.
cards.frontPrompt: What is impeachment by contradiction and what is impeachment by prior inconsistent statement, and how do they relate to each other?
cards.cloze: 1. Impeachment by {{c1::contradiction}} 1.1 {{c1::Contradiction}} allows use of **any evidence** to show that the witness (W) has made contradictory statements on {{c2::material issues}}. 2. Impeachment by {{c3::prior inconsistent statement (PIS)}} 2.1 A {{c3::PIS}} is a statement by W, made before trial, that {{c4::conflicts with W’s present testimony}}. 2.2 W’s {{c3::prior inconsistent statements}} may be used to {{c5::impeach}} W’s present testimony by showing W has changed or contradicted their story. 2.3 {{c3::PIS}} is a specific form of {{c1::contradiction}} focusing on W’s own prior words.
cards.easyContent: Impeachment by contradiction uses any evidence to show the witness has made conflicting statements on material issues. Impeachment by prior inconsistent statement (PIS) is a specific kind of contradiction that uses the witness’s own earlier statement that conflicts with their current testimony.
cards.mediumContent: Impeachment by contradiction allows a party to present any evidence that the witness has made contradictory statements on material issues, undermining credibility. Impeachment by prior inconsistent statement (PIS) uses the witness’s own earlier statement, made before trial, that conflicts with their present testimony. PIS is thus a particular form of contradiction using the witness’s prior words.
cards.hardContent: Impeachment by contradiction allows a party to introduce any evidence tending to show that the witness has made contradictory statements on material issues, thereby calling the witness’s credibility into question. Impeachment by prior inconsistent statement (PIS) involves showing that the witness made a prior statement, before trial, that is inconsistent with the witness’s present in-court testimony. By demonstrating this inconsistency, the examiner suggests the witness is unreliable or untruthful. PIS is therefore a subset of contradiction that focuses specifically on the witness’s own earlier statements rather than other contradictory evidence.
cards.mnemonic: Contradiction = any conflict; PIS = Prior Inconsistent Statement by witness.
cards.atomizationNotes: Basics of impeachment by contradiction vs prior inconsistent statements.
cards.clozeLite: Impeachment by {{c1::contradiction}} uses {{c2::any evidence}} of conflicting statements; {{c3::prior inconsistent statement}} impeachment uses {{c4::the witness’s own earlier statement}} and is a {{c5::subset of contradiction}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Prior Inconsistent Statements – Methods, Collateral Matters, and Foundation
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 012-2. Prior Inconsistent Statements – Methods, Collateral Matters, and Foundation
cards.front: Prior Inconsistent Statements – Methods, Collateral Matters, and Foundation
cards.backPlain: 1. Methods of proving a prior inconsistent statement (PIS) 1.1 A PIS may be established through: (a) Cross-examination of the witness; or (b) Extrinsic evidence (e.g., another witness, a document, or recording). 2. Collateral-matter limitation on extrinsic evidence 2.1 Extrinsic evidence of a PIS is **inadmissible** if the PIS relates **only to a collateral matter**. 2.2 A collateral matter is one that is relevant only to contradict the witness and does not bear on a substantive issue or another form of impeachment (e.g., bias). 3. Foundation requirement (opportunity to explain or deny) 3.1 Generally, the witness must be given an **opportunity to explain or deny** the PIS. 3.2 This opportunity may be given either before or after introducing the PIS, subject to the jurisdiction’s practice. 3.3 **Exception – hearsay declarant:** This foundation is **not required** for a PIS made by a hearsay declarant; the declarant need not be confronted with the statement before it is used for impeachment.
cards.frontPrompt: How can a prior inconsistent statement be proven, when is extrinsic evidence barred as collateral, and what foundation (opportunity to explain or deny) is generally required?
cards.cloze: 1. Methods of proving a {{c1::prior inconsistent statement (PIS)}} 1.1 A PIS may be established through {{c2::cross-examination}} of the witness or by {{c3::extrinsic evidence}}. 2. Collateral-matter limitation 2.1 {{c3::Extrinsic evidence}} of a PIS is **inadmissible** if the PIS relates only to a {{c4::collateral matter}}. 2.2 A {{c4::collateral matter}} is one relevant only to contradiction and not to any substantive issue or other valid impeachment theory. 3. Foundation requirement 3.1 Generally, the witness must be given an {{c5::opportunity to explain or deny}} the PIS. 3.2 This foundation is **not required** for a PIS made by a {{c6::hearsay declarant}}.
cards.easyContent: A prior inconsistent statement can be proven by cross-examining the witness or by extrinsic evidence. However, extrinsic evidence is not allowed if the inconsistency is only about a collateral matter. Usually, the witness must get a chance to explain or deny the prior statement, except when the statement was made by a hearsay declarant.
cards.mediumContent: A prior inconsistent statement (PIS) may be shown either by confronting the witness on cross-examination or by introducing extrinsic evidence like documents or other witnesses. Extrinsic evidence is barred if the inconsistency goes only to a collateral matter that is relevant solely for contradiction. Generally, the witness must be afforded an opportunity to explain or deny the PIS, but this confrontation requirement does not apply when the PIS is by a hearsay declarant.
cards.hardContent: To impeach by prior inconsistent statement (PIS), an examiner may either confront the witness with the inconsistent statement on cross-examination or prove the statement through extrinsic evidence, such as testimony from another witness or a prior written or recorded statement. Extrinsic evidence, however, is inadmissible when the PIS concerns only a collateral matter—i.e., an issue relevant solely to contradiction and not to any substantive issue, bias, or other recognized impeachment ground. As a general rule, the witness must be given an opportunity at some point to explain or deny the alleged inconsistency. This foundation requirement ensures fairness and allows the witness to address the inconsistency. An important exception applies to a PIS made by a hearsay declarant: the declarant need not be confronted with the statement and need not have an opportunity to explain or deny before the statement is used for impeachment.
cards.mnemonic: PIS: Proof by Cross or Extrinsic; No Extrinsic on Collateral; Confront unless Hearsay Declarant.
cards.atomizationNotes: Focuses on methods of proving PIS, collateral-matter limits, and foundation requirements.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::prior inconsistent statement}} may be shown by {{c2::cross-exam confrontation}} or {{c3::extrinsic evidence}}, but not if {{c4::collateral only}} and usually requires {{c5::chance to explain or deny}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Prior Inconsistent Statements – Hearsay vs Substantive Use
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 012-3. Prior Inconsistent Statements – Hearsay vs Substantive Use
cards.front: Prior Inconsistent Statements – Hearsay vs Substantive Use
cards.backPlain: 1. PIS as hearsay vs nonhearsay 1.1 A prior inconsistent statement (PIS) used to impeach is often an out-of-court statement offered to show inconsistency, not for its truth. 1.2 If the PIS is considered **hearsay** when offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted, its **use is limited**. 2. Hearsay PIS – impeachment-only use 2.1 If the PIS is hearsay and does not fall within a hearsay exemption or exception, it is admissible **only to impeach credibility**. 2.2 It is **inadmissible as substantive evidence** to prove the truth of the matter asserted. 2.3 The jury may consider it solely for its bearing on the witness’s **credibility**. 3. Nonhearsay or exception PIS – substantive use 3.1 If the PIS is **not hearsay** (e.g., under an exclusion such as a prior inconsistent statement given under oath in a prior proceeding) or falls under a **hearsay exemption or exception**, then it may be considered **for any purpose**. 3.2 In that case, the PIS is admissible **both** to impeach the witness and as **substantive evidence** to prove the truth of the matter asserted.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a prior inconsistent statement be used only to impeach, and when may it also be used as substantive evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted?
cards.cloze: 1. Hearsay PIS – impeachment only 1.1 If a prior inconsistent statement (PIS) is {{c1::hearsay}} and does **not** fall within a hearsay exemption or exception, it is admissible only to {{c2::impeach credibility}}. 1.2 It is **inadmissible** as {{c3::substantive evidence}} to prove the truth of the matter asserted and may be considered only for its impact on the witness’s {{c4::credibility}}. 2. Nonhearsay or exception PIS – substantive use 2.1 If the PIS is {{c5::not hearsay}} or falls under a hearsay {{c6::exemption or exception}}, it may be considered {{c7::for any purpose}}. 2.2 Such a PIS is admissible both for {{c2::impeachment}} and as {{c3::substantive evidence}} of the facts asserted in the statement.
cards.easyContent: If a prior inconsistent statement is hearsay and not within any exemption or exception, it can only be used to attack the witness’s credibility, not to prove the facts in it. If it is nonhearsay or within a hearsay exemption or exception, it can be used both to impeach and as substantive evidence.
cards.mediumContent: A prior inconsistent statement (PIS) that is hearsay may be admitted solely to impeach the witness’s credibility and not as substantive proof of the facts asserted. The jury may consider it only for its effect on credibility. But if the PIS is nonhearsay (for example, a prior inconsistent statement given under oath at a proceeding) or falls within a hearsay exemption or exception, it is admissible for any purpose, including as substantive evidence of the truth of what it asserts.
cards.hardContent: When a prior inconsistent statement (PIS) is offered solely to show that the witness has contradicted themselves, it is technically an out-of-court statement and may be hearsay if offered for its truth. If the PIS qualifies as hearsay and does not fall within any hearsay exemption or exception, it is admissible only to impeach the witness’s credibility, and the factfinder may not treat it as substantive proof of the facts stated. In contrast, when the PIS is categorized as nonhearsay (such as certain prior inconsistent statements given under oath at a formal proceeding) or fits within a recognized hearsay exemption or exception, the statement is admissible not only to impeach but also as substantive evidence. In that situation, the factfinder may rely on the PIS for any purpose, including to prove the truth of the matter asserted.
cards.mnemonic: PIS: If Hearsay Only, just Impeach; if Exception, it’s Evidence.
cards.atomizationNotes: Focuses on hearsay vs substantive use of prior inconsistent statements.
cards.clozeLite: A prior inconsistent statement that is {{c1::hearsay with no exemption/exception}} is used only to {{c2::impeach credibility}}, but if {{c3::nonhearsay or within a hearsay exemption/exception}}, it is {{c4::admissible as substantive evidence}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 019-1. Expert Opinions – Core Admissibility Requirements
cards.backPlain: Expert opinion testimony is admissible if several foundational requirements are met: 1. Helpful - The testimony must be helpful to the trier of fact. - The expert must use specialized knowledge to reach conclusions an average juror could not reach alone. 2. Qualified Expert - The expert must be qualified by special knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education. 3. Reasonable Degree of Certainty - The expert must believe in her opinion to a reasonable degree of certainty. 4. Proper Factual Basis - The opinion must be based on a proper factual foundation. The expert may rely on: - Evidence admitted at trial; - Personal knowledge (e.g., observations, examinations); or - Inadmissible information, so long as it is the type of information reasonably relied upon by experts in that field (e.g., data, other testimony, records, professional experience). 5. Reliable Principles and Methods (Non-Scientific Baseline) - The expert’s opinion must be based on reliable principles and methods reasonably relied upon by experts in the particular field (separate and apart from the special Daubert factors for scientific evidence).
cards.frontPrompt: What foundational requirements must be satisfied for expert opinion testimony to be admissible (helpfulness, qualification, certainty, basis, and reliability)?
cards.cloze: Expert opinion testimony is admissible only if several {{c1::foundational requirements}} are satisfied: 1. {{c2::Helpful}} – The testimony must assist the {{c3::trier of fact}} by applying specialized knowledge beyond the ken of average jurors. 2. {{c4::Qualified expert}} – The witness must have sufficient {{c5::knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education}}. 3. {{c6::Reasonable degree of certainty}} – The expert must believe the opinion to a {{c7::reasonable degree of professional certainty}}. 4. {{c8::Proper factual basis}} – The opinion must rest on: - {{c9::Admitted evidence}}, - The expert’s {{c10::personal knowledge}}, or - {{c11::Inadmissible information reasonably relied upon by experts in the field}}. 5. {{c12::Reliable principles and methods}} – The opinion must be grounded in {{c13::reliable principles and methods}} that are {{c14::reasonably relied upon by experts}} in that area.
cards.easyContent: Expert opinions are admissible only if they are helpful to the jury, given by a qualified expert, held to a reasonable degree of certainty, based on a proper factual foundation, and grounded in reliable principles and methods.
cards.mediumContent: To admit expert testimony, the court must find: (1) the testimony will help the trier of fact because it applies specialized knowledge beyond that of lay jurors; (2) the witness is qualified by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education; (3) the expert holds the opinion to a reasonable degree of certainty; (4) the opinion is based on a proper factual basis—admitted evidence, personal knowledge, or reasonably relied-on inadmissible information; and (5) the opinion uses reliable principles and methods reasonably relied upon by experts in the field.
cards.hardContent: Expert opinion testimony is admissible only if it meets core foundational requirements. First, it must be helpful to the trier of fact, in that it applies specialized knowledge to assist the jury or judge in understanding the evidence or determining a fact in issue, beyond what average jurors could do unaided. Second, the proffered expert must be qualified by specialized knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education. Third, the expert must hold the opinion to a reasonable degree of professional certainty. Fourth, there must be a proper factual basis: the expert may rely on admitted evidence, her own observations or examinations, and even inadmissible information, provided it is of a type reasonably relied upon by experts in the field. Fifth, the opinion must be grounded in reliable principles and methods that experts in the relevant discipline reasonably rely on, separate from any additional scientific-reliability (Daubert) analysis.
cards.mnemonic: HQ-RPR: Helpful, Qualified, Reasonable certainty, Proper basis, Reliable principles.
cards.clozeLite: Expert opinions are admissible only if they are {{c1::helpful}}, given by a {{c2::qualified expert}}, held to a {{c3::reasonable degree of certainty}}, based on a {{c4::proper factual basis}}, and use {{c5::reliable principles and methods}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Expert Opinions – Daubert Scientific Reliability Factors
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 019-2. Expert Opinions – Daubert Scientific Reliability Factors
cards.front: Expert Opinions – Daubert Scientific Reliability Factors
cards.backPlain: When an expert opinion is based on scientific evidence or methodology, the court applies Daubert-style reliability factors in addition to the core admissibility requirements. Daubert / Scientific Reliability Factors (nonexclusive): - Testability: Whether the theory or technique has been tested and is capable of being tested. - Peer review and publication: Whether it has been subject to peer review and publication. - Error rate: The known or potential error rate, and whether it is acceptably low. - General acceptance: Whether it is reasonably or generally accepted within the relevant scientific community. These factors guide the judge (as gatekeeper) in deciding whether the scientific principles and methods underlying the expert’s opinion are sufficiently reliable to be presented to the jury.
cards.frontPrompt: Under Daubert, what factors do courts consider to determine whether scientific expert testimony is sufficiently reliable to be admitted?
cards.cloze: For {{c1::scientific}} expert testimony, courts apply {{c2::Daubert}}-style reliability factors in addition to the usual expert foundations. Key (nonexclusive) factors include: - {{c3::Testability}} – Whether the theory or technique {{c4::has been tested and is capable of being tested}}. - {{c5::Peer review and publication}} – Whether it has been {{c6::subject to peer review and publication}}. - {{c7::Error rate}} – The {{c8::known or potential error rate}} and whether it is acceptably low. - {{c9::General acceptance}} – Whether the theory or technique is {{c10::reasonably or generally accepted in the relevant scientific community}}. These factors help the judge, acting as a {{c11::gatekeeper}}, decide if the scientific principles and methods underlying the opinion are {{c12::sufficiently reliable}} for the jury to hear.
cards.easyContent: For scientific expert testimony, courts use Daubert factors like testability, peer review/publication, known error rate, and general acceptance to assess whether the science is reliable.
cards.mediumContent: When an expert relies on scientific methods, the court applies Daubert-style factors to assess reliability: (1) whether the theory or technique has been tested and is testable; (2) whether it has been peer reviewed and published; (3) what the known or potential error rate is and whether it is low; and (4) whether it is reasonably or generally accepted in the relevant scientific community. These guide the judge in deciding whether the scientific foundation is reliable enough for admission.
cards.hardContent: In cases involving scientific experts, the court serves a gatekeeping function and evaluates the reliability of the scientific methodology using Daubert-style factors, in addition to the usual expert requirements. The central, nonexclusive factors are: (1) testability—whether the theory or technique has been empirically tested and is capable of being tested; (2) peer review and publication—whether it has been subjected to peer review and publication in scientific literature; (3) error rate—the known or potential rate of error associated with the methodology and whether that rate is acceptably low; and (4) general or reasonable acceptance in the relevant scientific community. The presence or absence of these considerations helps the judge decide whether the scientific principles and methods underlying the expert’s opinion are sufficiently reliable to go to the jury.
cards.mnemonic: Daubert T-PEA: Testable, Published, Error rate, Accepted.
cards.clozeLite: Daubert reliability looks to {{c1::testability}}, {{c2::peer review/publication}}, {{c3::known or potential error rate}}, and {{c4::general acceptance}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.topic: Expert Opinions – Scope and Ultimate Issues
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 019-3. Expert Opinions – Scope and Ultimate Issues
cards.front: Expert Opinions – Scope and Ultimate Issues
cards.backPlain: Scope of Expert Opinions and Ultimate Issues: 1. General Rule – Ultimate Issues - An expert may render an opinion on any ultimate issue in the case. - This includes opinions that effectively address elements or defenses, so long as they assist the trier of fact and are otherwise admissible. 2. Criminal-Case Limitation – Defendant’s Mental State - Exception: In a criminal case, an expert witness generally may not state an opinion about whether the defendant did or did not have the mental state or condition that constitutes an element of the crime charged or of a defense. - In other words, the expert cannot testify directly that the defendant "did" or "did not" possess the required mens rea (e.g., that the defendant "intended" or "knowingly" committed the act when that mental state is an element). - The expert may still describe diagnoses, symptoms, or hypotheticals, but cannot give a direct legal conclusion about the defendant’s actual mental state as an element of the offense or defense.
cards.frontPrompt: To what extent may experts testify on ultimate issues, and what special limitation applies in criminal cases regarding a defendant’s mental state?
cards.cloze: As to {{c1::scope}}, experts may generally offer opinions on {{c2::ultimate issues}} in the case, including matters that bear directly on elements or defenses, so long as the testimony is otherwise admissible. However, there is a key {{c3::criminal-case limitation}}: an expert may not state an opinion about whether the {{c4::defendant}} did or did not have the {{c5::mental state or condition}} that constitutes an {{c6::element of the crime charged}} or of a {{c7::defense}}. Thus, while an expert may describe diagnoses, symptoms, and hypotheticals, the expert cannot testify directly that the defendant {{c8::"did" or "did not" possess the required mens rea}} (such as specific intent or knowledge) when that mental state is itself a legal element.
cards.easyContent: Experts can usually testify about ultimate issues, but in criminal cases they cannot directly say whether the defendant had the required mental state that is an element of the crime or a defense.
cards.mediumContent: The rules allow experts to give opinions on ultimate issues, meaning they may address questions closely tied to elements or defenses, as long as the usual admissibility requirements are met. But in criminal cases, experts are generally barred from opining directly on whether the defendant actually possessed the mental state or condition that constitutes an element of the charged offense or a defense, though they may discuss diagnoses, symptoms, and hypotheticals.
cards.hardContent: Once foundational requirements are satisfied, experts may testify broadly on matters within their expertise, including ultimate issues in the case. This means an expert can articulate opinions that effectively bear on elements or defenses if such opinions help the trier of fact. However, in criminal cases there is a crucial limitation: an expert may not state an opinion about whether the defendant did or did not have the mental state or condition constituting an element of the crime charged or of a defense. The expert can still describe the defendant’s diagnoses, mental conditions, and symptoms, and answer hypotheticals framed in legal terms, but the expert must not give a direct legal conclusion that the defendant possessed or lacked the required mens rea when that mental state is itself an element the prosecution or defense must prove.
cards.mnemonic: Ultimate OK, but no expert Mens Rea verdict.
cards.clozeLite: Experts may opine on {{c1::ultimate issues}}, but in {{c2::criminal cases}} they cannot say if D had the {{c3::required mental state}} that is an {{c4::element of the crime or defense}}.

cards.rawHeader: Evidence 022-1. Physician–Patient Privilege – Definition and Requirements
cards.backPlain: 1. Nature of the physician–patient privilege. 1.1. Prevents disclosure of information confidentially conveyed by a patient to a physician. 1.2. It is a statutory privilege, not recognized in the Federal Rules of Evidence, but recognized and applied in most federal courts on the basis of state law. 2. Requirements for privileged physician–patient communications. 2.1. The communication is made for purposes of obtaining diagnosis or treatment. 2.2. The communication is pertinent to diagnosis or treatment. 2.3. The communication is intended by the patient to be confidential.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the physician–patient privilege, and what are the requirements for a communication to be protected?
cards.cloze: 1. Nature of the {{c1::physician–patient privilege}}. 1.1. Prevents disclosure of information {{c2::confidentially conveyed by a patient to a physician}}. 1.2. It is a {{c3::statutory privilege}}, not recognized in the {{c4::Federal Rules of Evidence}}, but recognized and applied in most federal courts on the basis of {{c5::state law}}. 2. Requirements for privileged physician–patient communications. 2.1. The communication is made for purposes of obtaining {{c6::diagnosis or treatment}}. 2.2. The communication is {{c7::pertinent to diagnosis or treatment}}. 2.3. The communication is {{c8::intended by the patient to be confidential}}.
cards.easyContent: Physician–patient privilege is a statutory privilege (applied via state law in federal court) that bars disclosure of confidential communications from a patient to a doctor when they are made for diagnosis or treatment, are medically pertinent, and are intended to be confidential.
cards.mediumContent: Physician–patient privilege prevents disclosure of information a patient confidentially conveys to a physician. It is not in the FRE but is a statutory privilege most federal courts apply through state law. A communication is privileged if it is (1) made for obtaining diagnosis or treatment, (2) pertinent to that diagnosis or treatment, and (3) intended by the patient to be confidential.
cards.hardContent: The physician–patient privilege is a statutory privilege, not codified in the Federal Rules of Evidence, but generally applied in federal courts by reference to state law. It protects information confidentially conveyed by a patient to a physician, so long as the communication is made for purposes of diagnosis or treatment, is medically pertinent to that diagnosis or treatment, and is intended by the patient to remain confidential. Only when all these requirements are met will the communication qualify as privileged.
cards.mnemonic: DOC: Diagnosis or treatment, Of medical relevance, Confidential intent.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::physician–patient privilege}} (a {{c2::statutory}} privilege) protects {{c3::confidential}} communications {{c4::for diagnosis or treatment}} that are {{c5::medically pertinent}}.

cards.rawHeader: Evidence 022-2. Physician–Patient Privilege – Exceptions
cards.backPlain: Exceptions: situations where physician–patient privilege does not apply. 1. Patient’s condition is a legal issue. 1.1. The privilege does not apply when the patient’s physical or mental condition is itself in issue, such as in a personal injury or medical condition claim. 2. Crime/tort/escape purposes. 2.1. The privilege does not apply when the physician’s services were sought to aid in the commission of a crime or tort, or to escape capture or apprehension. 3. Dispute between doctor and patient. 3.1. The privilege does not apply when there is a dispute between doctor and patient, such as a malpractice or fee dispute, where the communications are relevant to the controversy.
cards.frontPrompt: In what key situations does the physician–patient privilege not apply?
cards.cloze: Exceptions: situations where {{c1::physician–patient privilege does not apply}}. 1. {{c2::Patient’s condition is a legal issue}}. 1.1. The privilege does not apply when the patient’s physical or mental condition is itself in issue, such as in a {{c3::personal injury}} or medical condition claim. 2. {{c4::Crime/tort/escape purposes}}. 2.1. The privilege does not apply when the physician’s services were sought to aid in the commission of a {{c5::crime or tort}}, or to {{c6::escape capture or apprehension}}. 3. {{c7::Dispute between doctor and patient}}. 3.1. The privilege does not apply when there is a dispute between doctor and patient, such as a {{c8::malpractice}} or fee dispute, where the communications are relevant to the controversy.
cards.easyContent: Physician–patient privilege is lost when: (1) the patient’s condition is itself in issue (like a personal injury claim), (2) the doctor’s services are used to help commit a crime or tort or to escape capture, or (3) there is a dispute between doctor and patient, such as malpractice.
cards.mediumContent: Physician–patient privilege has three classic exceptions: (1) when the patient’s physical or mental condition is a legal issue in the case (e.g., personal injury or mental condition claims), (2) when the physician’s services were sought to aid in a crime, tort, or escape from capture, and (3) when there is a dispute between doctor and patient, such as malpractice or fee litigation, and the communications are relevant to resolving that dispute.
cards.hardContent: Even if all elements of physician–patient privilege are met, the privilege does not apply in key situations: (1) when the patient’s condition is itself placed in controversy by the patient’s claim or defense, such as in personal injury, wrongful death, or mental condition litigation; (2) when the physician’s services or consultation were sought to facilitate a crime, tort, or escape from arrest or capture—communications in furtherance of wrongdoing are not protected; and (3) when there is a dispute between doctor and patient, such as in malpractice, negligence, or fee disputes, to the extent the communications are relevant to that controversy.
cards.mnemonic: C-C-D: Condition, Crime, Doctor–patient dispute.
cards.clozeLite: Physician–patient privilege doesn’t apply when: {{c1::condition is in issue}}, {{c2::services further crime/tort/escape}}, or {{c3::doctor–patient dispute (e.g., malpractice)}}.

cards.rawHeader: Evidence 022-3. Psychotherapist/Social Worker–Patient Privilege
cards.backPlain: 1. Scope of psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege. 1.1. Protects material conveyed by the patient (client) to a psychotherapist or social worker. 1.2. Applies in all civil or criminal cases. 2. Requirements. 2.1. The client intends the communication to be confidential. 2.2. The communication is made to facilitate therapy or social work. 3. Relation to attorney–client privilege. 3.1. In most ways, this privilege operates similarly to the attorney–client privilege, protecting confidential communications made for the purpose of obtaining professional help or advice in the therapeutic context.
cards.frontPrompt: When does the psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege apply, and how is it similar to attorney–client privilege?
cards.cloze: 1. Scope of {{c1::psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege}}. 1.1. Protects material conveyed by the {{c2::patient (client)}} to a psychotherapist or social worker. 1.2. Applies in {{c3::all civil or criminal cases}}. 2. Requirements. 2.1. The client {{c4::intends the communication to be confidential}}. 2.2. The communication is made to {{c5::facilitate therapy or social work}}. 3. Relation to attorney–client privilege. 3.1. In most ways, this privilege operates similarly to the {{c6::attorney–client privilege}}, protecting confidential communications made for the purpose of obtaining professional help or advice in the therapeutic context.
cards.easyContent: Psychotherapist and social worker–patient privilege protects confidential client communications made to facilitate therapy or social work in civil and criminal cases, and it largely works like the attorney–client privilege.
cards.mediumContent: Psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege covers material a client conveys to a psychotherapist or social worker when the client intends confidentiality and the communication is made to facilitate therapy or social work. It applies in both civil and criminal cases and is generally treated like attorney–client privilege: confidential, purpose-of-professional-help communications are protected.
cards.hardContent: The psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege protects material a patient (client) conveys to a psychotherapist or licensed social worker, so long as the client intends the communication to be confidential and the communication is made in order to facilitate diagnosis, counseling, or social work services. This privilege applies across both civil and criminal cases. Functionally, courts treat it much like the attorney–client privilege: confidential communications for the purpose of obtaining professional therapeutic assistance are protected from compelled disclosure, subject only to any recognized exceptions under governing law.

cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege}} protects {{c2::confidential}} client communications made to {{c3::facilitate therapy or social work}} in {{c4::civil and criminal cases}}, and is treated like {{c5::attorney–client privilege}}.

cards.rawHeader: Evidence 030-1. Hearsay Exceptions – Declarant Unavailability Required
cards.backPlain: The following hearsay exceptions apply only if the declarant is unavailable (FRE 804): 1. Former testimony - Testimony given as a witness at another hearing or deposition - Offered against a party (or in civil cases, a predecessor in interest) who had an opportunity and similar motive to develop the testimony by direct, cross, or redirect examination. 2. Statements against interest - A statement that was against the declarant’s pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest when made - A reasonable person would not have made the statement unless it was true. 3. Dying declarations - A statement made under a sense of impending death - Concerning the cause or circumstances of what the declarant believed to be impending death - Admissible in civil cases and in homicide prosecutions. 4. Statements of personal or family history - Statements about the declarant’s own birth, adoption, marriage, divorce, legitimacy, relationship by blood or marriage, or similar facts of personal or family history - Or, in some cases, statements about another person’s family history if the declarant was related or intimately associated. 5. Statements offered against a party that wrongfully procured unavailability - A statement offered against a party who wrongfully caused, or acquiesced in wrongfully causing, the declarant’s unavailability as a witness - And did so with the intent to prevent the declarant from testifying.
cards.frontPrompt: Which hearsay exceptions require the declarant to be unavailable, and what are the basic requirements for each (former testimony, statements against interest, dying declarations, family history, and forfeiture by wrongdoing)?

Statements of {{c13::personal or family history}} - Statements about the declarant’s own birth, adoption, marriage, divorce, legitimacy, relationship by blood or marriage, or similar facts of personal or family history - Or, in some cases, statements about {{c14::another person’s}} family history if the declarant was related or intimately associated. 5. Statements offered against a party that {{c15::wrongfully procured unavailability}} - A statement offered against a party who wrongfully caused, or acquiesced in wrongfully causing, the declarant’s {{c16::unavailability}} as a witness - And did so with the {{c17::intent to prevent}} the declarant from testifying.
cards.easyContent: Some hearsay exceptions only apply if the declarant is unavailable: former testimony (with prior opportunity and similar motive to examine), statements against the declarant’s own interest, dying declarations, statements about personal or family history, and statements offered against a party who wrongfully caused the declarant’s unavailability.
cards.mediumContent: Under FRE 804, the key unavailability-based exceptions are: (1) former testimony, given at another hearing or deposition and now offered against a party (or predecessor in interest) who had an opportunity and similar motive to examine; (2) statements against interest, where a reasonable person would not have made the pecuniary, proprietary, or penal self-damaging statement unless true; (3) dying declarations, made under a sense of impending death about its cause or circumstances, admissible in civil cases and homicide prosecutions; (4) statements of personal or family history (birth, marriage, relationships, etc.); and (5) statements offered against a party who wrongfully caused the declarant’s unavailability with intent to prevent testimony (forfeiture by wrongdoing).
cards.hardContent: The unavailability-required hearsay exceptions (FRE 804) are: 1) Former testimony: Prior under-oath testimony at another hearing or deposition, now offered against a party (or, in civil cases, a predecessor in interest) who had both an opportunity and a similar motive to develop the testimony by examination. 2) Statements against interest: A statement that was so contrary to the declarant’s pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest at the time it was made that a reasonable person would not have made it unless it was true. 3) Dying declarations: A statement made while the declarant believed death was imminent, concerning the cause or circumstances of what the declarant believed to be impending death, admissible in civil actions and homicide prosecutions. 4) Statements of personal or family history: Statements about the declarant’s own birth, adoption, marriage, divorce, legitimacy, relationship by blood or marriage, or similar family history facts, and in some cases comparable statements about another person’s family history if the declarant was related or intimately associated. 5) Forfeiture by wrongdoing: A statement offered against a party who wrongfully caused (or acquiesced in causing) the declarant’s unavailability as a witness, with the intent to prevent the declarant from testifying; the wrongdoer forfeits hearsay and confrontation objections.
cards.mnemonic: For unavailable declarants, think "FID-HW": Former, Interest, Dying, History, Wrongdoing.

cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::FRE 804}}, unavailability exceptions include {{c2::former testimony}}, {{c3::statements against interest}}, {{c4::dying declarations}}, {{c5::family history}}, and {{c6::forfeiture by wrongdoing}}.

cards.subject: Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Evidence 030-2. Hearsay Exceptions – Declarant Availability Immaterial
cards.backPlain: The following hearsay exceptions apply regardless of whether the declarant is available; availability is immaterial: 1. Present state of mind - A statement of the declarant’s then-existing state of mind (e.g., intent, plan, motive) or emotional, sensory, or physical condition. 2. Excited utterance - A statement relating to a startling event or condition - Made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement that it caused. 3. Present sense impression - A statement describing or explaining an event or condition - Made while or immediately after the declarant perceived it. 4. Statements for medical diagnosis or treatment - Statements made for (and reasonably pertinent to) medical diagnosis or treatment - Describing medical history, symptoms, or the general cause of the condition. 5. Past recollection recorded - A record that reflects a matter the witness once knew about but now cannot recall well enough to testify fully and accurately - Made or adopted when the matter was fresh in the witness’s memory - Accurately reflects the witness’s knowledge. 6. Business records - Records of acts, events, conditions, opinions, or diagnoses - Made at or near the time by (or from information transmitted by) someone with knowledge - Kept in the course of a regularly conducted business activity - Making the record was a regular practice of that activity. 7. Public records or reports - Records or statements of a public office that set out the office’s activities, observations under a legal duty to report, or factual findings from legally authorized investigations (subject to limitations in criminal cases). 8. Judgments and prior convictions - Evidence of a final judgment of conviction for a crime punishable by death or imprisonment for more than one year, offered to prove any fact essential to the judgment (and certain other judgment records in limited contexts). 9. Ancient documents - Statements in a document at least 20 years old that is authenticated. 10. Documents affecting property interests - Statements in a document that affects an interest in property (e.g., deeds, wills, mortgages), if the matter stated was relevant to the document’s purpose and is authenticated. 11. Learned treatises - Statements in a reliable, authoritative treatise, periodical, or pamphlet, used with an expert on direct or cross, and read into evidence (but not received as an exhibit). 12. Family records - Statements of personal or family history contained in family Bibles, genealogies, inscriptions on rings, engravings on urns, tombstones, or similar family records. 13. Market reports and similar commercial publications - Market quotations, lists, directories, or other published compilations that are generally relied upon by the public or by persons in particular occupations.

cards.easyContent: Most hearsay exceptions do not depend on whether the declarant is available. These include present state of mind, excited utterances, present sense impressions, medical diagnosis/treatment statements, past recollection recorded, business and public records, judgments and prior convictions, ancient documents, documents affecting property interests, learned treatises, family records, and market reports or similar commercial publications.
cards.mediumContent: When availability is immaterial, the main hearsay exceptions include: (1) statements of present state of mind or condition; (2) excited utterances; (3) present sense impressions; (4) statements for medical diagnosis or treatment; (5) past recollection recorded; (6) business records; (7) public records or reports; (8) judgments and prior convictions; (9) ancient documents; (10) documents affecting property interests; (11) learned treatises; (12) family records; and (13) market reports and similar commercial publications. These exceptions generally focus on reliability from contemporaneity, professional or public duty to record, necessity, or inherent trustworthiness of the document or publication.
cards.hardContent: Hearsay exceptions where the declarant’s availability is immaterial include: 1) Present state of mind: Then-existing state of mind (intent, plan, motive) or emotional, sensory, or physical condition, often used to show what the declarant intended or felt. 2) Excited utterance: A statement relating to a startling event made while the declarant is still under the stress of excitement, before reflective fabrication is likely. 3) Present sense impression: A description or explanation of an event or condition made while or immediately after the declarant perceives it, relying on contemporaneity for reliability. 4) Statements for medical diagnosis or treatment: Statements made to medical personnel or others for purposes of diagnosis or treatment, describing medical history, symptoms, or general cause, so long as reasonably pertinent. 5) Past recollection recorded: A writing that records a matter the witness once knew but now cannot recall fully and accurately; made or adopted when the matter was fresh and accurately reflects knowledge. The record may be read into evidence. 6) Business records: Regularly kept records of acts, events, conditions, opinions, or diagnoses, made at or near the time by someone with knowledge, kept in the course of a regularly conducted business activity, where making the record was a regular practice. 7) Public records or reports: Records or statements of a public office setting out the office’s activities, matters observed under a legal duty to report, or factual findings from a legally authorized investigation (subject to limitations, especially in criminal cases for law-enforcement reports). 8) Judgments and prior convictions: Final judgments of conviction for serious crimes (death or >1 year imprisonment), offered to prove any fact essential to the judgment, plus some civil judgment uses. 9) Ancient documents: Statements in authenticated documents at least 20 years old. 10) Documents affecting property interests: Statements in authenticated documents that affect an interest in property (like deeds, wills, mortgages), where the statement is relevant to the document’s purpose. 11) Learned treatises: Statements from reliable, authoritative treatises, periodicals, or pamphlets established as such by expert testimony or judicial notice; statements may be read into evidence but not received as exhibits. 12) Family records: Statements of personal or family history contained in family Bibles, genealogies, inscriptions on engravings, tombstones, or similar items. 13) Market reports and similar commercial publications: Market quotations, lists, directories, or other published compilations generally relied on by the public or by persons in particular occupations, whose reliability stems from industry or public reliance.
